A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a violation of subsection (a) of this section, imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $10,000 or both; and
for a violation of subsection (b) or (c) of this section, imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section shall pay for the restoration of any damaged or defaced real or personal property in a cemetery to the owner of the property or the owner of the cemetery.
This section does not prohibit the removal of human remains or a funerary object from an abandoned cemetery if:

paragraph.text: the removal is authorized in writing by the State’s Attorney of the county in which the cemetery containing the human remains or funerary object is located; and
the human remains or funerary object are placed in an accessible place in a permanent cemetery.

subsection.text: A person may not commit adultery.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be fined $10.
This section does not apply to a person if:

paragraph.text: the person’s previous lawful spouse has been absent from the person for a continuous period of 7 years; and
the person does not know whether the person’s previous lawful spouse is living at the time of the subsequent marriage ceremony.

subsection.text: While lawfully married to a living person, a person may not enter into a marriage ceremony with another.
A person who violates this section is guilty of the felony of bigamy and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 9 years.
An indictment or warrant for bigamy is sufficient if it substantially states:

“(name of defendant) on (date), in (county), having a living spouse, feloniously entered into a marriage ceremony with (name of subsequent spouse), in violation of § 10-502 of the Criminal Law Article, against the peace, government, and dignity of the State.”.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Animal” means a living creature except a human being.

paragraph.text: “Cruelty” means the unnecessary or unjustifiable physical pain or suffering caused or allowed by an act, omission, or neglect.
“Cruelty” includes torture and torment.

subsection.text: “Humane society” means a society or association incorporated in Maryland for the prevention of cruelty to animals.

section.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly that each animal in the State be protected from intentional cruelty, including animals that are:

paragraph.text: privately owned;
strays;
domesticated;
feral;
farm animals;
corporately or institutionally owned; or
used in privately, locally, State, or federally funded scientific or medical activities.

section.text: Sections 10-601 through 10-608 of this subtitle do not apply to:

paragraph.text: customary and normal veterinary and agricultural husbandry practices including dehorning, castration, tail docking, and limit feeding;
research conducted in accordance with protocols approved by an animal care and use committee, as required under the federal Animal Welfare Act or the federal Health Research Extension Act;

an activity that may cause unavoidable physical pain to an animal, including food processing, pest elimination, animal training, and hunting, if the person performing the activity uses the most humane method reasonably available; or
normal human activities in which the infliction of pain to an animal is purely incidental and unavoidable.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: overdrive or overload an animal;
deprive an animal of necessary sustenance;
inflict unnecessary suffering or pain on an animal;
cause, procure, or authorize an act prohibited under item (1), (2), or (3) of this subsection; or

if the person has charge or custody of an animal, as owner or otherwise, unnecessarily fail to provide the animal with nutritious food in sufficient quantity, necessary veterinary care, proper drink, air, space, shelter, or protection from the weather.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
As a condition of sentencing, the court may order a defendant convicted of violating this section to participate in and pay for psychological counseling.
As a condition of probation, the court may prohibit a defendant from owning, possessing, or residing with an animal.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly attend a deliberately conducted dogfight as a spectator.
A person may not knowingly attend as a spectator a deliberately conducted event that uses a fowl, cock, or other bird to fight with another fowl, cock, or other bird.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $2,500 or both.
As a condition of sentencing, the court may order a defendant convicted of violating this section to participate in and pay for psychological counseling.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: intentionally mutilate, torture, cruelly beat, or cruelly kill an animal;
cause, procure, or authorize an act prohibited under item (1) of this subsection; or
except in the case of self–defense, intentionally inflict bodily harm, permanent disability, or death on an animal owned or used by a law enforcement unit.
A person who violates this section is guilty of the felony of aggravated cruelty to animals and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
As a condition of sentencing, the court may order a defendant convicted of violating this section to participate in and pay for psychological counseling.
As a condition of probation, the court may prohibit a defendant from owning, possessing, or residing with an animal.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: use or allow a dog to be used in a dogfight;
arrange or conduct a dogfight;
possess, own, sell, transport, or train a dog with the intent to use the dog in a dogfight; or
knowingly allow premises under the person’s ownership, charge, or control to be used to conduct a dogfight.
A person who violates this section is guilty of the felony of aggravated cruelty to animals and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
As a condition of sentencing, the court may order a defendant convicted of violating this section to participate in and pay for psychological counseling.
In this section, “implement of cockfighting” means any implement or device intended or designed:

subparagraph.text: to enhance the fighting ability of a fowl, cock, or other bird; or
for use in a deliberately conducted event that uses a fowl, cock, or other bird to fight with another fowl, cock, or other bird.

paragraph.text: “Implement of cockfighting” includes:

subparagraph.text: a gaff;
a slasher;
a postiza;
a sparring muff; and
any other sharp implement designed to be attached in place of the natural spur of a gamecock or other fighting bird.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: use or allow the use of a fowl, cock, or other bird to fight with another animal;
possess, with the intent to unlawfully use, an implement of cockfighting;
arrange or conduct a fight in which a fowl, cock, or other bird fights with another fowl, cock, or other bird;
possess, own, sell, transport, or train a fowl, cock, or other bird with the intent to use the fowl, cock, or other bird in a cockfight; or
knowingly allow premises under the person’s ownership, charge, or control to be used to conduct a fight in which a fowl, cock, or other bird fights with another fowl, cock, or other bird.
A person who violates this section is guilty of the felony of aggravated cruelty to animals and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
As a condition of sentencing, the court may order a defendant convicted of violating this section to participate in and pay for psychological counseling.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section, if an officer of a humane society sees a person committing a misdemeanor that involves cruelty to an animal, the officer shall arrest and bring before the District Court the person committing the misdemeanor.

In Calvert County, if an officer of a humane society or an animal control officer appointed by the County Commissioners or the County Commissioners’ designee sees a person committing a misdemeanor that involves cruelty to an animal, the officer shall arrest and bring before the District Court the person committing the misdemeanor.
In Baltimore County, the Baltimore County Department of Health, Division of Animal Control shall enforce this section.
This section does not apply to a person giving away an animal:

paragraph.text: as an agricultural project;
for conservation purposes; or
that is intended for slaughter.

subsection.text: Without the approval of the Secretary of Agriculture, a person may not give away a live animal as:

paragraph.text: a prize for, or inducement to enter, a contest, game, or other competition;
an inducement to enter a place of amusement; or
an incentive to make a business agreement if the offer is to attract trade.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person may not kill or allow a dog or cat to be killed by use of:

paragraph.text: a decompression chamber;
carbon monoxide gas; or
curariform drugs.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person who owns, possesses, or has custody of a domestic animal may not drop or leave the animal on a road, in a public place, or on private property with the intent to abandon the animal.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100.
This section does not apply to:

paragraph.text: a biomedical facility that is licensed by the United States Department of Agriculture; or
an animal that is accompanied by a signed statement from a licensed veterinarian stating that the animal’s dam is incapacitated for humane or medical reasons and cannot care for the animal.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person may not sell or distribute in the State or bring into the State for the purpose of sale or distribution a domestic dog or cat less than 8 weeks of age unless accompanied by its dam.
A person may give an unaccompanied dog or cat to:

subparagraph.text: an animal shelter or pound that is operated or supported by a government; or
a humane society.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
For purposes of humane disposal, a court may seize an animal brought into this State in violation of this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “chick” means a chicken, duckling, or other fowl under the age of 3 weeks.
This section does not prohibit the sale or display of a chick in proper facilities by a breeder or store engaged in the business of selling chicks for commercial breeding and raising.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: sell, offer for sale, barter, or give away a chick as a pet, toy, premium, or novelty; or
color, dye, stain, or otherwise change the natural color of a chick.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $25.

If an owner or custodian of an animal is convicted of an act of animal cruelty, the court may order the removal of the animal or any other animal at the time of conviction for the protection of the animal.

paragraph.text: An officer or authorized agent of a humane society, or a police officer or other public official required to protect animals may seize an animal if necessary to protect the animal from cruelty.

subparagraph.text: An animal that a medical and scientific research facility possesses may be removed under this subsection only after review by and a recommendation from the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, Center for Veterinary Public Health.
The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: conduct an investigation within 24 hours after receiving a complaint; and
within 24 hours after completing the investigation, report to the State’s Attorney for the county in which the facility is situated.

paragraph.text: If an animal is impounded, yarded, or confined without necessary food, water, or proper attention, is subject to cruelty, or is neglected, an officer or authorized agent of a humane society, a police officer, another public official required to protect animals, or any invited and accompanying veterinarian licensed in the State, may:

subparagraph.text: enter the place where the animal is located and supply the animal with necessary food, water, and attention; or
remove the animal if removal is necessary for the health of the animal.

paragraph.text: A person who enters a place under paragraph (1) of this subsection is not liable because of the entry.
A person who removes an animal under subsection (c) of this section shall notify the animal’s owner or custodian of:

subparagraph.text: the removal; and
any administrative remedies that may be available to the owner or custodian.

paragraph.text: If an administrative remedy is not available, the owner or custodian may file a petition for the return of the animal in the District Court of the county in which the removal occurred within 10 days after the removal.

subsection.text: An animal is considered a stray if:

paragraph.text: an owner or custodian of the animal was notified under subsection (d) of this section and failed to file a petition within 10 days after removal; or
the owner or custodian of the animal is unknown and cannot be ascertained by reasonable effort for 20 days to determine the owner or custodian.

subsection.text: This section does not allow:

paragraph.text: entry into a private dwelling; or
removal of a farm animal without the prior recommendation of a veterinarian licensed in the State.

subsection.text: In Baltimore County, the Baltimore County Department of Health, Division of Animal Control or an organization that the Baltimore County government approves shall enforce this section.
This section does not apply to premises:

paragraph.text: where dogs are kept or bred solely for medical or related research or laboratory tests;
operated by a licensed and regularly practicing veterinarian; or
where hunting dogs are housed, if the buying, selling, trading, or breeding is incidental to the main purposes of housing, keeping, and using dogs.

To determine if dogs are being treated inhumanely in violation of this subtitle or other law, an authorized director of a humane society, accompanied by a sheriff or a deputy sheriff, may inspect a premises:

subparagraph.text: where a person is engaged in the business of buying, selling, trading, or breeding dogs; or
of a kennel where 25 or more dogs are kept.

paragraph.text: A person who inspects premises under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall give prior written notice of the time and date of the inspection to the owner or occupant of the premises.
In Baltimore City, the Baltimore City Health Department shall enforce this section.
In Baltimore County, the Baltimore County Department of Health, Division of Animal Control or an organization that the Baltimore County government approves shall enforce this section.

subsection.text: In this section, “animal control unit” means the local organization or governmental unit that the appropriate local governmental body designates to house, care for, and control domestic animals of unknown ownership.
An animal control unit shall dispose of an unclaimed dog or cat only by:

paragraph.text: placing the animal in a suitable home;
retaining the animal in the animal control unit; or
humanely destroying the animal.

subsection.text: A domestic animal that is impounded by an animal control unit may not be sold, placed, or destroyed until the animal has been carefully inspected for a tag, tattoo, or other identification to ascertain the owner and:

paragraph.text: 72 hours have elapsed after notice has been given to the owner;
if the owner cannot be notified, 72 hours have elapsed after the animal is impounded;
the animal is seriously diseased or severely injured; or
the animal is under 3 months of age.
An owner who retrieves an animal from an animal control unit shall pay all fees, costs, and expenses incurred by the animal control unit.

The necessary expenses for food and attention given to an animal under this section may be collected from the owner, and the animal is not exempt from levy and sale on execution of a judgment for the expenses.
A new owner with whom an animal is placed under subsection (b)(1) of this section may be charged an adoption fee.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person may not willfully and maliciously give poison or ground glass to a dog, or expose poison or ground glass, with the intent that a dog ingest it.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each violation.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Dangerous dog” means a dog that:

subparagraph.text: without provocation has killed or inflicted severe injury on a person; or
is determined by the appropriate unit of a county or municipal corporation under subsection (c) of this section to be a potentially dangerous dog and, after the determination is made:

sub-subparagraph.text: bites a person;
when not on its owner’s real property, kills or inflicts severe injury on a domestic animal; or
attacks without provocation.

subparagraph.text: “Owner’s real property” means real property owned or leased by the owner of a dog.
“Owner’s real property” does not include a public right-of-way or a common area of a condominium, apartment complex, or townhouse development.

paragraph.text: “Severe injury” means a physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a dog owned by and working for a governmental or law enforcement unit.
An appropriate unit of a county or municipal corporation may determine that a dog is potentially dangerous if the unit:

paragraph.text: finds that the dog:

subparagraph.text: has inflicted a bite on a person while on public or private real property;
when not on its owner’s real property, has killed or inflicted severe injury on a domestic animal; or
has attacked without provocation; and

paragraph.text: notifies the dog owner in writing of the reasons for this determination.

subsection.text: A dog owner may not:

paragraph.text: leave a dangerous dog unattended on the owner’s real property unless the dog is:

subparagraph.text: confined indoors;
in a securely enclosed and locked pen; or
in another structure designed to restrain the dog; or

paragraph.text: allow a dangerous dog to leave the owner’s real property unless the dog is leashed and muzzled, or is otherwise securely restrained and muzzled.

subsection.text: An owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who sells or gives the dog to another shall notify in writing:

paragraph.text: the authority that made the determination under subsection (c) of this section, of the name and address of the new owner of the dog; and
the person taking possession of the dog, of the dangerous behavior or potentially dangerous behavior of the dog.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: willfully and maliciously interfere with, injure, destroy, or tamper with a horse used for racing or breeding or for a competitive exhibition of skill, breed, or stamina;

willfully start, instigate, engage in, or further an act that interferes with, injures, destroys, or tampers with a horse used for racing or breeding or for a competitive exhibition of skill, breed, or stamina; or
commit an act that tends to interfere with, injure, destroy, or tamper with a horse used for racing or breeding or for a competitive exhibition of skill, breed, or stamina.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to imprisonment of not less than 1 year and not exceeding 3 years.

paragraph.text: This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: a research facility or federal research facility licensed under the federal Animal Welfare Act;
an exhibitor licensed under the federal Animal Welfare Act that displays the animals specified in subsection (b) of this section in a public setting as the exhibitor’s primary function;

a person who possesses a valid license or permit issued by the Department of Natural Resources to import, sell, trade, barter, possess, breed, or exchange an animal specified in subsection (b) of this section;
an animal sanctuary that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is a nonprofit organization qualified under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code;
operates a place of refuge for abused, neglected, impounded, abandoned, orphaned, or displaced wildlife;
does not conduct commercial activity with respect to any animal of which the organization is an owner; and
does not buy, sell, trade, lease, or breed any animal except as an integral part of the species survival plan of the American Zoo and Aquarium Association;

subparagraph.text: an animal control officer under the jurisdiction of the State or a local governing authority, a law enforcement officer acting under the authority of this subtitle, or a private contractor of a county or municipal corporation that is responsible for animal control operations;

a person who holds a valid license to practice veterinary medicine in the State and treats the animal specified in subsection (b) of this section in accordance with customary and normal veterinary practices; and
a person who is not a resident of the State and is in the State for 10 days or less for the purpose of traveling between locations outside of the State.

This section does not prohibit a person who had lawful possession of an animal specified in subsection (b) of this section on or before May 31, 2006, from continuing to possess that animal if the person provides written notification to the local animal control authority on or before August 1, 2006.
The notification shall include:

sub-subparagraph.text: the person’s name, address, and telephone number;
the number and type of animals being kept; and
a photograph of the animal or a description of a tattoo or microchip identification of the animal.

paragraph.text: This section does not prohibit a person who has a disability that severely limits mobility from possessing an animal specified in subsection (b) of this section if that animal is:

subparagraph.text: trained to perform tasks for the owner by an organization described in Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code; and
dedicated to improving the quality of life of a person who has a disability that severely limits mobility.

subsection.text: A person may not import into the State, offer for sale, trade, barter, possess, breed, or exchange a live:

paragraph.text: fox, skunk, raccoon, or bear;
caiman, alligator, or crocodile;
member of the cat family other than the domestic cat;
hybrid of a member of the cat family and a domestic cat if the hybrid weighs over 30 pounds;
member of the dog family other than the domestic dog;
hybrid of a member of the dog family and a domestic dog;
nonhuman primate, including a lemur, monkey, chimpanzee, gorilla, orangutan, marmoset, loris, or tamarin; or
poisonous snake in the family groups of Hydrophidae, Elapidae, Viperidae, or Crotolidae.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

subparagraph.text: if an individual, a fine not exceeding $1,000; or
if not an individual, a fine not exceeding $10,000.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this section may be enforced by:

subparagraph.text: any State or local law enforcement officer; or
the local animal control authority for the jurisdiction where the violation occurs.

paragraph.text: An animal specified in subsection (b) of this section may be immediately seized if:

subparagraph.text: there is probable cause to believe that the possession of the animal is in violation of this section; or
the animal poses a risk to public health or public safety.

paragraph.text: An animal specified in subsection (b) of this section that is seized may be returned to the person who had possession of the animal at the time the animal was seized only if it is established that:

subparagraph.text: possession of the animal by the person is not a violation of this section; and
the return of the animal does not pose a risk to public health or public safety.
Notice that the animal was seized shall be served on the person who had possession of the animal at the time the animal was seized by:

sub-subparagraph.text: posting a copy of the notice at the place where the animal was seized;
regular and certified mail, return receipt requested; or
delivering the notice to a person residing on the property from which the animal was seized.

subparagraph.text: The notice shall include:

sub-subparagraph.text: a description of the animal seized;
the authority for and the purpose of the seizure;
the time, place, and circumstances of the seizure;
a contact person and telephone number;
a statement that the person from whom the animal was seized may:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: post security to prevent disposition of the animal; and
request a hearing concerning the seizure;

sub-subparagraph.text: a statement that failure to post security or request a hearing within 10 days of the date of the notice will result in the disposition of the animal; and

a statement that, unless a court finds that the seizure of the animal was not justified, the actual costs of the care, keeping, and disposal of the animal are the responsibility of the person from whom the animal was seized.

subparagraph.text: Before a seizure under paragraph (1) of this subsection occurs, the person in possession of the animal to be seized may request that the animal remain in the person’s physical custody for 30 days after the date the animal was to be seized.
During the 30 days provided in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, the person shall take all necessary actions to comply with this section.
At any reasonable time during the 30-day period, the local animal control authority may inspect the premises where the animal is being kept.

If a person who retains possession of an animal under paragraph (4) of this subsection is not in compliance with this section after the 30-day period has expired, the local animal control authority shall seize the animal and place it in a holding facility that is appropriate for the species.
The authority seizing an animal under this paragraph shall provide notice of the seizure in the same manner as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection.
A person from whom an animal was seized may request a hearing in the District Court within 10 days of the seizure.
A hearing shall be held as soon as practicable to determine the validity of the seizure and the disposition of the animal.

Unless the court finds that the seizure of the animal was not justified by law, a person from whom the animal specified in subsection (b) of this section is seized is liable for all actual costs of care, keeping, and disposal of the animal.

The costs required under this paragraph shall be paid in full unless a mutually satisfactory agreement is made between the local animal control authority and the person claiming an interest in the animal.

If there is no request for a hearing within 10 days of the notice or if the court orders a permanent and final disposition of the animal, the local animal control authority may take steps to find long-term placement of the animal with another appropriate facility that is equipped for the continued care of the particular species of the animal.
If there is no entity that is suitable for the care of the animal, the animal may be euthanized.

subsection.text: This section does not limit a county or municipality from enacting laws or adopting regulations that are more restrictive pertaining to any potentially dangerous animals, including those specified in subsection (b) of this section.

If the owner of an animal specified in subsection (b) of this section dies without making arrangements for the transfer of custody of the animal to another person, the animal may be turned over to one of the organizations specified in subsection (a)(1) of this section or euthanized if no suitable location can be found in a reasonable amount of time.
A person may not shoot, kill, or maim a carrier pigeon.
A person may not entrap, catch, or detain a carrier pigeon that has:

paragraph.text: the owner’s name stamped on the carrier pigeon’s wing or tail; or
a leg band that includes the owner’s initials, name, or number.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $10 for each violation.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Collar” means a device constructed of nylon, leather, or similar material specifically designed to be used around the neck of a dog.
“Restraint” means a chain, rope, tether, leash, cable, or other device that attaches a dog to a stationary object or trolley system.

subsection.text: A person may not leave a dog outside and unattended by use of a restraint:

paragraph.text: that unreasonably limits the movement of the dog;
that uses a collar that:

subparagraph.text: is made primarily of metal; or
is not at least as large as the circumference of the dog’s neck plus 1 inch;

paragraph.text: that restricts the access of the dog to suitable and sufficient clean water or appropriate shelter;
in unsafe or unsanitary conditions; or
that causes injury to the dog.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “flag” includes any size flag, standard, color, ensign, or shield made of any substance or represented or produced on any substance, that purports to be a flag, standard, color, ensign, or shield of the United States or of this State.
This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: an act allowed by the statutes of the United States or of this State, or by the regulations of the armed forces of the United States; or
a document or product, stationery, ornament, picture, apparel, or jewelry that depicts a flag without a design or words on the flag and that is not connected with an advertisement.

subsection.text: This section applies to a flag of the United States or of this State, or a flag that is authorized by law of the United States or of this State.
For exhibition or display, a person may not place or cause to be placed a word, figure, mark, picture, design, or advertisement of any nature on a flag.
A person may not publicly exhibit a flag with a word, figure, mark, picture, design, or advertisement printed, painted, or produced on or attached to the flag.

A person may not publicly display for sale, manufacture, or otherwise, or sell, give, or possess for sale or for use as a gift or for any other purpose, an article of merchandise or receptacle on which a flag is produced or attached to advertise, decorate, or mark the merchandise.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500.
A person may not intentionally mutilate, deface, destroy, burn, trample, or use a flag:

paragraph.text: in a manner intended to incite or produce an imminent breach of the peace; and
under circumstances likely to incite or produce an imminent breach of the peace.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: This subtitle shall be construed to carry out its general purpose and to make uniform the laws of the states that enact it.
This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland Uniform Flag Law.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advertising purposes” means the purpose of propagandizing in connection with the commercial:

paragraph.text: sale of a product;
offering of a service; or
exhibition of entertainment.

subsection.text: “Sadomasochistic abuse” means:

paragraph.text: flagellation or torture committed by or inflicted on an individual who is:

subparagraph.text: nude;
wearing only undergarments; or
wearing a revealing or bizarre costume; or

paragraph.text: binding, fettering, or otherwise physically restraining an individual who is:

subparagraph.text: nude;
wearing only undergarments; or
wearing a revealing or bizarre costume.

subsection.text: “Sexual conduct” means:

paragraph.text: human masturbation;
sexual intercourse; or
whether alone or with another individual or animal, any touching of or contact with:

subparagraph.text: the genitals, buttocks, or pubic areas of an individual; or
breasts of a female individual.

subsection.text: “Sexual excitement” means:

paragraph.text: the condition of the human genitals when in a state of sexual stimulation;
the condition of the human female breasts when in a state of sexual stimulation; or
the sensual experiences of individuals engaging in or witnessing sexual conduct or nudity.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly sell or offer to sell to a minor:

paragraph.text: a picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, motion picture, film, or other visual representation or image of an individual or portion of the human body that depicts sadomasochistic abuse, sexual conduct, or sexual excitement;
a book, magazine, paperback, pamphlet, or other written or printed matter however reproduced, that contains:

subparagraph.text: any matter enumerated in item (1) of this section;
obscene material; or
explicit verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sadomasochistic abuse, sexual conduct, or sexual excitement; or

paragraph.text: a sound recording that contains:

subparagraph.text: obscene material; or
explicit verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sadomasochistic abuse, sexual conduct, or sexual excitement.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
This section applies to a motion picture show or other presentation, whether animated or live, that wholly or partly:

paragraph.text: depicts or reveals:

subparagraph.text: sadomasochistic abuse;
sexual conduct; or
sexual excitement; or

paragraph.text: includes obscene material or explicit verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sexual conduct.

subsection.text: For monetary consideration or other valuable commodity or service, a person may not knowingly:

paragraph.text: exhibit to a minor without the presence of the minor’s parent or guardian a motion picture show or other presentation described in subsection (a) of this section;
sell to a minor an admission ticket or other means to gain entrance to a motion picture show or other presentation described in subsection (a) of this section; or
admit a minor without the presence of the minor’s parent or guardian to premises where a motion picture show or other presentation described in subsection (a) of this section is exhibited.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

A person who operates or is employed in a sales, cashier, or managerial capacity in a retail establishment may not knowingly allow a minor without the presence of the minor’s parent or guardian to enter or remain on any premises where an item or activity detailed in § 11-102(a) of this subtitle is shown, displayed, or depicted.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

In Harford County and Cecil County, a person who operates a bookstore or entertainment venue in which an item or activity described in § 11-102 or § 11-103 of this subtitle is shown, displayed, or depicted and constitutes a majority of the items or activities offered for sale or rental by the bookstore or entertainment venue:

paragraph.text: shall require each individual upon entering the premises to display a driver’s license or an identification card that substantiates the individual’s age; and
may not knowingly allow a minor to remain on the premises.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
A person may not knowingly display for advertising purposes a picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, or other visual representation or image of an individual or portion of a human body that:

paragraph.text: depicts sadomasochistic abuse;
depicts sexual conduct;
depicts sexual excitement; or
contains a verbal description or narrative account of sadomasochistic abuse, sexual conduct, or sexual excitement.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly allow a display described in subsection (a) of this section on premises that the person owns, rents, or manages.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: For purposes of §§ 11-101 through 11-105 of this subtitle, an employee of a person who operates premises where a public display violates this subtitle is presumed to have been the operator of the premises when the violation occurred if the employee was on the premises at the time of the violation.
A person convicted of indecent exposure is guilty of a misdemeanor and is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Distribute” means to transfer possession.
“Knowingly” means having knowledge of the character and content of the matter.
“Matter” means:

paragraph.text: a book, magazine, newspaper, or other printed or written material;
a picture, drawing, photograph, motion picture, or other pictorial representation;
a statue or other figure;
a recording, transcription, or mechanical, chemical, or electrical reproduction; or
any other article, equipment, machine, or material.

subsection.text: “Sadomasochistic abuse” has the meaning stated in § 11-101 of this title.
“Sexual conduct” has the meaning stated in § 11-101 of this title.
“Sexual excitement” has the meaning stated in § 11-101 of this title.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: knowingly send or cause to be sent any obscene matter into the State for sale or distribution;
knowingly bring or cause to be brought any obscene matter into the State for sale or distribution;
in the State prepare, publish, print, exhibit, distribute, or offer to distribute any obscene matter; or
possess any obscene matter in the State with the intent to distribute, offer to distribute, or exhibit.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

The State’s Attorney may maintain an action for an injunction in the circuit court against a person to prevent the sale, further sale, distribution, further distribution, acquisition, publication, or possession within the State of any book, magazine, pamphlet, newspaper, story paper, writing paper, picture, card, drawing, photograph, motion picture film or showing, or any article, item, or instrument the use of which is obscene.

The circuit court may enjoin the sale or distribution of a book, magazine, motion picture film or showing, or other publication or item that is prohibited under this section from sale or distribution.

After being served a summons and complaint in an action by the State’s Attorney under this section, a person who sells, distributes, or acquires the enjoined material is chargeable with knowledge of the contents of the materials described in this section.
The defendant is entitled to a trial of the issues within 1 day after joinder of issue.
The court shall render a decision within 2 days after the conclusion of the trial.
If an order or judgment is entered in favor of the State’s Attorney, the final order or judgment shall contain provisions:

subparagraph.text: directing the person to surrender the obscene matter to the peace officer designated by the court or the county sheriff; and
directing the peace officer or county sheriff to seize and destroy the obscene matter.

paragraph.text: In an action brought under this section, the State’s Attorney is not:

subparagraph.text: required to file a bond before an injunction order is issued;
liable for costs; or
liable for damages sustained because of the injunction order if judgment is rendered in favor of the defendant.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Distribute” includes to rent.
“Illicit sex” means:

subparagraph.text: human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal;
acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse, or sodomy; or
fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals.

paragraph.text: “Item” means a:

subparagraph.text: still picture or photograph;
book, pocket book, pamphlet, or magazine;
videodisc, videotape, video game, film, or computer disc; or
recorded telephone message.

paragraph.text: “Obscene” means:

subparagraph.text: that the average adult applying contemporary community standards would find that the work, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest;

that the work depicts sexual conduct specified in subsection (b) of this section in a way that is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material; and
that the work, taken as a whole, lacks serious artistic, educational, literary, political, or scientific value.

paragraph.text: “Partially nude figure” means a figure with:

subparagraph.text: less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic region, buttocks, or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola; or
human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered.

paragraph.text: A person may not willfully or knowingly display or exhibit to a minor an item:

subparagraph.text: the cover or content of which is principally made up of an obscene description or depiction of illicit sex; or
that consists of an obscene picture of a nude or partially nude figure.

paragraph.text: A person may not willfully or knowingly engage in the business of displaying, exhibiting, selling, showing, advertising for sale, or distributing to a minor an item:

subparagraph.text: the cover or content of which is principally made up of an obscene description or depiction of illicit sex; or
that consists of an obscene picture of a nude or partially nude figure.

paragraph.text: If a newsstand or other place of business is frequented by minors, the owner, operator, franchisee, manager, or an employee with managerial responsibility may not openly and knowingly display at the place of business an item whose sale, display, exhibition, showing, or advertising is prohibited by paragraph (2) of this subsection.

subsection.text: The provision of services or facilities by a telephone company under a tariff approved by the Public Service Commission is not a violation of subsection (b) of this section relating to recorded telephone messages.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Allegany, Anne Arundel, Charles, Howard, Somerset, Wicomico, and Worcester counties.

paragraph.text: A person may not prepare, give, direct, present, perform or participate in an obscene performance, exhibition, drama, play, show, dancing exhibition, tableau, or other entertainment in which individuals perform or participate live in an obscene manner in the presence of individuals who have paid any kind of consideration to observe the exhibition or performance.

An owner, lessee, or manager of a building, garden, place, room, structure, or theater may not knowingly allow or assent to the use of the premises for the types of exhibitions prohibited by paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly:

paragraph.text: write or create advertising or otherwise promote the sale or distribution of matter the person represents or holds out to be obscene; or
solicit the publication of advertising that promotes the sale or distribution of matter the person represents or holds out to be obscene.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

A person may not knowingly require a purchaser or consignee to receive obscene matter as a condition to a sale, allocation, consignment, or delivery for resale of a paper, magazine, book, periodical, publication, or other merchandise.
In response to a person’s return of or failure to accept obscene matter, a person may not knowingly:

subparagraph.text: deny or revoke a franchise;
threaten to deny or revoke a franchise; or
impose a financial or other penalty.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: cause, induce, solicit, or knowingly allow a minor to engage as a subject in the production of obscene matter or a visual representation or performance that depicts a minor engaged as a subject in sadomasochistic abuse or sexual conduct;
photograph or film a minor engaging in an obscene act, sadomasochistic abuse, or sexual conduct;
use a computer to depict or describe a minor engaging in an obscene act, sadomasochistic abuse, or sexual conduct;
knowingly promote, advertise, solicit, distribute, or possess with the intent to distribute any matter, visual representation, or performance:

subparagraph.text: that depicts a minor engaged as a subject in sadomasochistic abuse or sexual conduct; or

in a manner that reflects the belief, or that is intended to cause another to believe, that the matter, visual representation, or performance depicts a minor engaged as a subject of sadomasochistic abuse or sexual conduct; or

paragraph.text: use a computer to knowingly compile, enter, transmit, make, print, publish, reproduce, cause, allow, buy, sell, receive, exchange, or disseminate any notice, statement, advertisement, or minor’s name, telephone number, place of residence, physical characteristics, or other descriptive or identifying information for the purpose of engaging in, facilitating, encouraging, offering, or soliciting unlawful sadomasochistic abuse or sexual conduct of or with a minor.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or a fine not exceeding $25,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 20 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.

subparagraph.text: This paragraph applies only if the minor’s identity is unknown or the minor is outside the jurisdiction of the State.

In an action brought under this section, the State is not required to identify or produce testimony from the minor who is depicted in the obscene matter or in any visual representation or performance that depicts the minor engaged as a subject in sadomasochistic abuse or sexual conduct.

paragraph.text: The trier of fact may determine whether an individual who is depicted in an obscene matter, or any visual representation or performance as the subject in sadomasochistic abuse or sexual conduct, was a minor by:

subparagraph.text: observation of the matter depicting the individual;
oral testimony by a witness to the production of the matter, representation, or performance;
expert medical testimony; or
any other method authorized by an applicable provision of law or rule of evidence.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly possess and intentionally retain a film, videotape, photograph, or other visual representation showing an actual child under the age of 16 years:

paragraph.text: engaged as a subject of sadomasochistic abuse;
engaged in sexual conduct; or
in a state of sexual excitement.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $2,500 or both.

A person who violates this section, having previously been convicted under this section, is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or a fine not exceeding $10,000 or both.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section may be construed to prohibit a parent from possessing visual representations of the parent’s own child in the nude unless the visual representations show the child engaged:

paragraph.text: as a subject of sadomasochistic abuse; or
in sexual conduct and in a state of sexual excitement.

subsection.text: It is an affirmative defense to a charge of violating this section that the person promptly and in good faith:

paragraph.text: took reasonable steps to destroy each visual representation; or
reported the matter to a law enforcement agency.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Child pornography” means any electronic image or visual depiction that is unlawful under § 11-207 or § 11-208 of this subtitle.

“Controlled or owned”, with respect to a server or other storage device, means to be entirely owned by an interactive computer service provider or to be subject to exclusive management by an interactive computer service provider by agreement or otherwise.

“Interactive computer service provider” means an entity that provides a service that provides or enables computer access via the Internet by multiple users to a computer server or similar device used for the storage of graphics, video, or images.

subsection.text: An investigative or law enforcement officer who receives information that an item of alleged child pornography resides on a server or other storage device controlled or owned by an interactive computer service provider shall:

paragraph.text: contact the interactive computer service provider that controls or owns the server or other storage device where the item of alleged child pornography is located;
inform the interactive computer service provider of the provisions of this section; and

request that the interactive computer service provider voluntarily comply with this section and remove the item of alleged child pornography from its server or other storage device, if practicable, within 5 business days.

If the interactive computer service provider does not voluntarily remove the item of alleged child pornography within the time period established in subsection (b) of this section, the investigative or law enforcement officer shall apply for a court order of authorization to remove the item of alleged child pornography in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 4 of the Courts Article.
The application for a court order shall:

subparagraph.text: identify the item of alleged child pornography discovered on the server or other storage device controlled or owned by an interactive computer service provider;
provide its location on the server or other storage device in the form of an Internet protocol (IP) address or uniform resource locator (URL);
state the grounds for the issuance of the order;
verify that the item of alleged child pornography resides on the server or other storage device controlled or owned by the interactive computer service provider;
describe the steps taken to obtain voluntary compliance of the interactive computer service provider with this section;
inform the interactive computer service provider of its right to request a hearing on the application; and
state the name and title of the affiant.

paragraph.text: The investigative or law enforcement officer shall serve the application on the interactive computer service provider.
The interactive computer service provider has the right to request a hearing before the court imposes any penalty under this section.

subsection.text: The court shall review the application and testimony, if offered, and, upon a finding of probable cause, issue an order that:

paragraph.text: an item of child pornography resides on a server or other storage device controlled or owned by the interactive computer service provider or is accessible to persons located in the State;
there is probable cause to believe that the item violates § 11-207 or § 11-208 of this subtitle;

the interactive computer service provider shall remove the item residing on a server or other storage device controlled or owned by the interactive computer service provider within 5 business days after receiving the order, if practicable;
failure of the interactive computer service provider to comply with the court’s order is a violation of this section;

the removal of the item on the server or other storage device controlled or owned by the interactive computer service provider may not unreasonably interfere with a request by a law enforcement agency to preserve records or other evidence;
the process of removal shall be conducted in a manner that prevents the removal of images, information, or data not otherwise subject to removal under this section; and
provides the interactive computer service provider notice and opportunity for a hearing before the court imposes any penalty under this section.
The Office of the State’s Attorney shall serve the court’s order on the interactive computer service provider.
The order shall be accompanied by:

subparagraph.text: the application made under subsection (c) of this section;

notification requiring the interactive computer service provider to remove the item residing on a server or other storage device controlled or owned by the interactive computer service provider, if practicable, within 5 business days after receiving the order;
notification of the criminal penalties for failure to remove the item of child pornography;
notification of the right to appeal the court’s order; and
contact information for the Office of the State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: An interactive computer service provider who is served with a court order under subsection (e) of this section shall remove the item of child pornography that is the subject of the order within 5 business days after receiving the court order, if practicable.

paragraph.text: An interactive computer service provider may petition the court for relief for cause from an order issued under subsection (d) of this section.
The petition may be based on considerations of:

subparagraph.text: the cost or technical feasibility of compliance with the order; or
the inability of the interactive computer service provider to comply with the order without also removing data, images, or information that are not subject to this section.

Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, an interactive computer service provider shall report the location of an item of child pornography to the State Police if the item of child pornography:

sub-subparagraph.text: resides on a server or other storage device that is:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: controlled or owned by the interactive computer service provider; and
located in the State; or

sub-subparagraph.text: based on information apparent to the provider at the time of the report or discovery of an item of child pornography, pertains to a subscriber or user of the interactive computer service who resides in the State.

subparagraph.text: Subparagraph (i) of this paragraph does not apply to an interactive computer service provider if:

sub-subparagraph.text: federal law expressly provides for or permits the referral of a report of an item of child pornography to a state or local law enforcement agency; and
the interactive computer service provider complies with the federal law.

paragraph.text: An interactive computer service provider who knowingly and willfully fails to report the information required under paragraph (1) of this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

subparagraph.text: for a first violation, a fine not exceeding $5,000;
for a second violation, a fine not exceeding $20,000; and
for each subsequent violation, a fine not exceeding $30,000.

subsection.text: An interactive computer service provider who willfully violates subsection (f) of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, a fine not exceeding $5,000;
for a second violation, a fine not exceeding $20,000; and
for each subsequent violation, a fine not exceeding $30,000.

subsection.text: An interactive computer service provider who willfully violates subsection (f) or (h) of this section may be prosecuted, indicted, tried, and convicted in any county in or through which:

paragraph.text: the interactive computer service provider provides access to the Internet;
any communication from the interactive computer service provider traveled; or
the communication from the interactive computer service provider originated or terminated.
This section does not impose a duty on an interactive computer service provider actively to monitor its service or affirmatively to seek evidence of an item of child pornography on its service.

This section does not apply to the interactive computer service provider’s transmission or routing of, or intermediate temporary storage or caching of, an image, information, or data that otherwise is subject to this section.

subsection.text: An interactive computer service provider may not be held liable for any action taken in good faith to comply with this section.

A person may not hire, employ, or use an individual, if the person knows, or possesses facts under which the person should reasonably know, that the individual is a minor, to do or assist in doing an act described in § 11-203 of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
for each subsequent violation, imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

A person having a bona fide scientific, educational, governmental, artistic, news, or other similar justification for possessing or distributing prohibited matter is not subject to the prohibitions and penalties imposed by this subtitle.

A distribution made in accordance with a bona fide scientific, educational, governmental, artistic, news, or other similar justification is not subject to the prohibitions and penalties imposed by this subtitle.

subsection.text: A justification is not bona fide under this section if a reasonable person would find that a dominant purpose of the depiction of an individual under the age of 16 years engaging in sexual conduct is to arouse or gratify sexual desire in either the violator, the individual under the age of 16 years, or the viewer.

section.text: When the conviction of a person for a violation of this subtitle becomes final, the court may order the destruction of any matter or advertisement that was the basis of the person’s conviction and that remains in the possession or under the control of the court, the State, or a law enforcement unit.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Assignation” means the making of an appointment or engagement for prostitution or any act in furtherance of the appointment or engagement.
“Prostitution” means the performance of a sexual act, sexual contact, or vaginal intercourse for hire.
“Sexual act” has the meaning stated in § 3–301 of this article.
“Sexual contact” has the meaning stated in § 3–301 of this article.

“Sexually explicit performance” means a public or private, live, photographed, recorded, or videotaped act or show in which the performer is wholly or partially nude, and which is intended to sexually arouse or appeal to the prurient interest of patrons or viewers.
“Solicit” means urging, advising, inducing, encouraging, requesting, or commanding another.
“Vaginal intercourse” has the meaning stated in § 3–301 of this article.

section.text: A person charged with a crime under this subtitle may also be prosecuted and sentenced for violating any other applicable law.

paragraph.text: A person may not knowingly:

subparagraph.text: take or cause another to be taken to any place for prostitution;
place, cause to be placed, or harbor another in any place for prostitution;
persuade, induce, entice, or encourage another to be taken to or placed in any place for prostitution;
receive consideration to procure for or place in a house of prostitution or elsewhere another with the intent of causing the other to engage in prostitution or assignation;

engage in a device, scheme, or continuing course of conduct intended to cause another to believe that if the other did not take part in a sexually explicit performance, the other or a third person would suffer physical restraint or serious physical harm; or

destroy, conceal, remove, confiscate, or possess an actual or purported passport, immigration document, or government identification document of another while otherwise violating or attempting to violate this subsection.

paragraph.text: A parent, guardian, or person who has permanent or temporary care or custody or responsibility for supervision of another may not consent to the taking or detention of the other for prostitution.
A person may not violate subsection (a) of this section involving a victim who is a minor.

A person may not knowingly take or detain another with the intent to use force, threat, coercion, or fraud to compel the other to marry the person or a third person or perform a sexual act, sexual contact, or vaginal intercourse.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a person who violates subsection (a) of this section is guilty of the misdemeanor of human trafficking and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
A person who violates subsection (a) of this section is subject to § 5–106(b) of the Courts Article.

paragraph.text: A person who violates subsection (b) of this section is guilty of the felony of human trafficking and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 25 years or a fine not exceeding $15,000 or both.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section may be charged, tried, and sentenced in any county in or through which the person transported or attempted to transport the other.

paragraph.text: A person who knowingly benefits financially or by receiving anything of value from participation in a venture that includes an act described in subsection (a) or (b) of this section is subject to the same penalties that would apply if the person had violated that subsection.

A person who knowingly aids, abets, or conspires with one or more other persons to violate any subsection of this section is subject to the same penalties that apply for a violation of that subsection.

subsection.text: A person may not receive or acquire money or proceeds from the earnings of a person engaged in prostitution with the intent to:

paragraph.text: promote a crime under this subtitle;
profit from a crime under this subtitle; or
conceal or disguise the nature, location, source, ownership, or control of money or proceeds of a crime under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or a fine not exceeding $10,000 or both.
A person who violates this section is subject to § 5-106(b) of the Courts Article.
For purposes of prostitution or committing a crime under Title 3, Subtitle 3 of this article, a person may not:

paragraph.text: persuade or entice or aid in the persuasion or enticement of an individual under the age of 16 years from the individual’s home or from the custody of the individual’s parent or guardian; or
knowingly secrete or harbor or aid in the secreting or harboring of an individual under the age of 16 years who has been persuaded or enticed in the manner described in item (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 10 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
A person who violates this section is subject to § 5-106(b) of the Courts Article.
A person may not knowingly:

paragraph.text: engage in prostitution or assignation by any means;
keep, set up, occupy, maintain, or operate a building, structure, or conveyance for prostitution or assignation;
allow a building, structure, or conveyance owned or under the person’s control to be used for prostitution or assignation;
allow or agree to allow a person into a building, structure, or conveyance for prostitution or assignation; or
procure or solicit or offer to procure or solicit for prostitution or assignation.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Candidate” has the meaning stated in § 1-101 of the Election Law Article.

paragraph.text: “Credit” means payment by a credit card or promissory note.
“Credit” includes selling or pledging personal property in exchange for cash or tokens.
“Gaming device” means:

subparagraph.text: a gaming table, except a billiard table, at which a game of chance is played for money or any other thing or consideration of value; or
a game or device at which money or any other thing or consideration of value is bet, wagered, or gambled.

paragraph.text: “Gaming device” includes a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, chance book, and bingo.

subsection.text: “Gaming event” means:

paragraph.text: a bingo game;
a carnival;
a bazaar;
a raffle;
a benefit performance; or
any other event at which a gaming device is operated.

subsection.text: “Organization” includes:

paragraph.text: a fraternal, religious, civic, patriotic, educational, or charitable organization;
a volunteer fire company, rescue squad, or auxiliary unit;
a veterans’ organization or club;
a bona fide nonprofit organization that is raising money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose; or
any organization that is authorized to conduct a gaming event under Subtitle 1 or 2 of this title or Title 13 of this article.

subsection.text: “Political committee” has the meaning stated in § 1-101 of the Election Law Article.
“Token” means a poker chip, bingo chip, or other device commonly used instead of money in the playing of a gaming device.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: bet, wager, or gamble;
make or sell a book or pool on the result of a race, contest, or contingency;

establish, keep, rent, use, or occupy, or knowingly allow to be established, kept, rented, used, or occupied, all or a part of a building, vessel, or place, on land or water, within the State, for the purpose of:

subparagraph.text: betting, wagering, or gambling; or
making, selling, or buying books or pools on the result of a race, contest, or contingency; or

paragraph.text: receive, become the depository of, record, register, or forward, or propose, agree, or pretend to forward, money or any other thing or consideration of value, to be bet, wagered, or gambled on the result of a race, contest, or contingency.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment for not less than 6 months and not exceeding 1 year or a fine of not less than $200 and not exceeding $1,000 or both.

paragraph.text: The provisions of this subsection apply only in Baltimore City.
A person who violates this section may be charged by a citation.

A citation for a violation of this section may be issued to a person by a police officer authorized to make arrests in Baltimore City if there is probable cause to believe that the person is committing or has committed a violation of this section.
A citation issued under this subsection shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the person charged;
the statute allegedly violated;
the location, date, and time that the violation occurred;
the fine or term of imprisonment that may be imposed;
a notice stating that prepayment of a fine is not allowed;
a notice that the court shall promptly send the person charged a summons to appear for trial; and
the signature of the police officer issuing the citation.
The police officer who issued the citation shall forward to the appropriate court a copy of the citation.
The court shall promptly schedule the case for trial and summon the defendant to appear.
Willful failure of the defendant to respond to the summons is contempt of court.

subsection.text: For money or any other thing or consideration of value, a person may not play:

paragraph.text: the game called “thimbles”;
the game called “little joker”;
dice or the game commonly called “craps”; or
any other gaming device or fraudulent trick.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment for not less than 6 months and not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $100 or both.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: keep a gaming device, or all or a part of a building, vessel, or place, on land or water within the State for the purpose of gambling;
own, rent, or occupy all or a part of a building, vessel, or place and knowingly allow a gaming device to be kept in the building, vessel, or place;
lease or rent all or a part of a building, vessel, or place to be used for the purpose of gambling;
deal at a gaming device or in a building, vessel, or place for gambling;
manage a gaming device or a building, vessel, or place for gambling; or
have an interest in a gaming device or the profits of a gaming device.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment for not less than 6 months and not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.
This section:

paragraph.text: applies notwithstanding the issuance of a license or permit through or by a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of the State; and
does not authorize an act that is otherwise prohibited by law.

subsection.text: A person may not bet, wager, or gamble or keep, conduct, maintain, or operate a gaming device on:

paragraph.text: a vessel or a part of a vessel on water within the State, except as provided in § 6-209 of the Transportation Article; or
all or a part of a building or other structure that is built on or over water within the State, if the building or other structure cannot be entered from the shore of the State by a person on foot.

subsection.text: To conduct, maintain, or operate a gaming device, a person may not establish, keep, rent, use, or occupy, or knowingly allow to be established, kept, rented, used, or occupied:

paragraph.text: a vessel on water within the State; or
a building or other structure that is built on or over water within the State, if the building or other structure cannot be entered from the shore of the State by a person on foot.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine of not less than $200 and not exceeding $1,000 or both for each violation.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, Subtitle 2 of this title, or Title 13 of this article and except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a bona fide charitable organization in this State may conduct a raffle for the exclusive benefit of the charitable organization if the prize awarded is real property:

subparagraph.text: to which the charitable organization holds title; or
for which the charitable organization has the ability to convey title.

paragraph.text: A charitable organization may not conduct more than two raffles of real property in a calendar year.
The Secretary of State may adopt regulations governing a raffle of real property by a charitable organization under this subsection.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article and except as otherwise provided in this subsection, a political committee or candidate for public office may conduct a raffle if the prizes awarded are money or merchandise.

subparagraph.text: The cost of a raffle ticket under this subsection may not exceed $5.
An individual may not purchase more than $50 worth of tickets.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not relieve a political committee or candidate from the reporting and record keeping requirements under the Election Law Article.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a credit union organized under Title 6 of the Financial Institutions Article may conduct a savings promotion raffle under § 6–716 of the Financial Institutions Article.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a depository institution, as defined in § 1–211 of the Financial Institutions Article, may conduct a savings promotion raffle under § 1–211 of the Financial Institutions Article.
The prohibition in subsection (b) of this section applies notwithstanding a license or permit granted through or by a county, municipal corporation, or other political subdivision of this State.
This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: pari-mutuel betting conducted under the Maryland Horse Racing Act;
bingo, carnivals, raffles, bazaars, or similar games of entertainment; or
mechanical or electrical devices, commonly known as slot machines, that are authorized in the State and that require the insertion of a coin or token.

subsection.text: A person may not conduct or operate with pari-mutuel betting, or with any similar form of betting, wagering, or gambling:

paragraph.text: the game, contest, or event commonly known as “jai alai”; or
any other game, contest, or event.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine of not less than $200 and not exceeding $1,000 for each violation.

An organization that operates a gaming event authorized under this subtitle, Subtitle 2 of this title, or Title 13 of this article may not accept credit from a person to allow that person to play a gaming device at the gaming event.
Subsection (a) of this section does not prohibit an organization from accepting a token instead of money from a person who has paid the organization money for the use of the token.

An organization that violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $1,000 or loss of privileges to conduct a gaming event not exceeding 60 days or both.
A person may not willfully, knowingly, and unlawfully cause or attempt to cause the prearrangement or predetermination of the results of a horse race.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
A person who loses money at a gaming device that is prohibited by this subtitle, Subtitle 2 of this title, or Title 13 of this article:

paragraph.text: may recover the money as if it were a common debt; and
is a competent witness to prove the loss.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a person may not recover money or any other thing that the person won by betting at a gaming device prohibited by this subtitle, Subtitle 2 of this title, or Title 13 of this article.

section.text: If a law enforcement officer has a reason to suspect a gaming device is kept unlawfully at a place, the law enforcement officer shall:

paragraph.text: visit the place; and
charge all persons who violate a law that prohibits gambling.
An indictment for violating the prohibition against gaming is sufficient if it states that the defendant kept a gaming device.
The indictment need not state the particular kind of gaming or gaming device involved in the alleged violation.

subsection.text: A defendant, on timely request, may obtain a bill of particulars.

The Office of the Attorney General, the State Lottery Commission, the Department of State Police, local law enforcement units, and the court shall construe liberally this title relating to gambling and betting to prevent the activities prohibited.
A decision by the State Lottery Commission shall be the final determination as to whether a gaming device being operated in the State is:

paragraph.text: a legal gaming device or device consistent with the provisions of this article; and
being operated in a lawful manner under this article.
