subsection.text: If a local law enforcement unit fails to promptly enforce a final determination made under subsection (b) of this section, the State Lottery Commission shall refer the matter to the Department of State Police for enforcement of the law.
In this section, “fantasy competition” includes any online fantasy or simulated game or contest such as fantasy sports, in which:

paragraph.text: participants own, manage, or coach imaginary teams;
all prizes and awards offered to winning participants are established and made known to participants in advance of the game or contest;

the winning outcome of the game or contest reflects the relative skill of the participants and is determined by statistics generated by actual individuals (players or teams in the case of a professional sport); and
no winning outcome is based:

subparagraph.text: solely on the performance of an individual athlete; or
on the score, point spread, or any performances of any single real–world team or any combination of real–world teams.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of this or any other title, the prohibitions against betting, wagering, and gambling do not apply to participation in a fantasy competition.
The Comptroller may adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this section.

section.text: In this subtitle, “lottery device” means a policy, certificate, or other thing by which a person promises or guarantees that a number, character, ticket, or certificate will, when an event or contingency occurs, entitle the purchaser or holder to receive money, property, or evidence of debt.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, this subtitle applies to all lotteries, including those authorized by any other state or foreign country.
This subtitle does not apply to the State lottery established under Title 9, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: hold a lottery in this State; or
sell a lottery device in the State for a lottery drawn in this State or elsewhere.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be sentenced to imprisonment for not less than 3 months and not exceeding 12 months or a fine of not less than $200 and not exceeding $1,000 or both for each violation.

In addition to the penalty provided under subsection (b) of this section, a person who gives money or any other thing to purchase or obtain a lottery device, for each lottery device purchased or obtained, may recover $50 from:

paragraph.text: the person to whom the money or other thing was given; or
any person who aided or abetted that person.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: keep a house, office, or other place for the purpose of selling or bartering a lottery device in violation of § 12-203 of this subtitle; or
allow a house or office that the person owns to be used for the purpose of selling or bartering a lottery device in violation of § 12-203 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who knows that the person’s house or office is being used for the purpose of selling or bartering a lottery device in violation of § 12-203 of this subtitle is deemed to be allowing the house or office to be used for those purposes.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
This section does not apply to a person who possesses:

paragraph.text: an item that is prohibited under this section that was obtained to procure or furnish evidence of a violation of this subtitle; or
a lottery ticket or slip issued by this State or another government.

subsection.text: A person may not:

paragraph.text: bring a lottery device into the State; or
possess a book, list, slip, or record of:

subparagraph.text: the numbers drawn in a lottery in this State or another state or country;
a lottery device; or
money received or to be received from the sale of a lottery device.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
This section does not apply to a lottery conducted by a government.
A person may not print, write, or publish an account of a lottery that describes:

paragraph.text: when or where the lottery is to be drawn;
any prize available in the lottery;
the price of a lottery ticket or share of a lottery ticket; or
where a lottery ticket may be obtained.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 60 days or a fine not exceeding $100 or both.
A person may not:

paragraph.text: insure or receive consideration for insuring for or against the drawing of a lottery ticket or part of a lottery ticket;

receive money, property, or evidence of debt in consideration of an agreement to repay or deliver the money, property, or evidence of debt, if a lottery ticket or a part of a lottery ticket is drawn or not drawn on a particular day or in a particular order;
if contingent on the results of a lottery, and whether or not consideration is paid, promise or agree to:

subparagraph.text: pay or deliver money, property, or evidence of debt; or
refuse to do anything for the benefit of another; or

paragraph.text: publish a notice of an intent to perform or notice of a proposal to perform items (1) through (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment of not less than 3 months and not exceeding 6 months or a fine of not less than $100 and not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: A court shall interpret §§ 12-201 through 12-207 of this subtitle liberally to treat as a lottery ticket any ticket, part of a ticket, or lottery device by which money is paid or another item is delivered when, in the nature of a lottery, an event or contingency occurs.
A grant, bargain, or transfer of real estate, goods, a right of action, or personal property is void if it occurs while engaging in, or aiding or assisting in a lottery.

subsection.text: Any recovery of a penalty for a violation of any of the provisions of this subtitle relating to a lottery, whether by indictment or action of debt, or before a justice of the peace before July 5, 1971, or before any court of competent jurisdiction, is considered a first conviction under this section.

A person convicted a second or subsequent time of a violation of any of the provisions of this subtitle relating to a lottery is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.

paragraph.text: An indictment for violating the prohibition against the drawing of lotteries or the selling of lottery devices is sufficient if it states that the defendant drew a lottery or sold a lottery device.
The indictment need not state the particular kind of lottery scheme involved in the alleged violation.

subsection.text: The defendant, on timely request, is entitled to a bill of particulars.

A person may not directly or indirectly barter, sell, or trade or offer by publication or in any other manner to barter, sell, or trade goods or merchandise, in a package or in bulk, in exchange for a scheme or device constituting a gift enterprise.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction shall be sentenced to a fine of not less than $50 for each violation.

section.text: In this subtitle:

paragraph.text: “slot machine” means a machine, apparatus, or device that:

subparagraph.text: operates or can be made to operate by inserting, depositing, or placing with another person money, a token, or another object; and
through the element of chance, the reading of a game of chance, the delivery of a game of chance, or any other outcome unpredictable by the user, awards the user:

sub-subparagraph.text: money, a token, or other object that represents or that can be converted into money; or
the right to receive money, a token, or another object that represents and can be converted into money;

paragraph.text: “slot machine” includes:

subparagraph.text: a machine, apparatus, or device described in item (1) of this section that also sells, delivers, or awards merchandise, money, or some other tangible thing of value;
a pinball machine or console machine that pays off in merchandise; and

a machine, apparatus, or device described in item (1) of this section, regardless of whether the machine, apparatus, or device delivers a game through the Internet or offers Internet or other services; and

paragraph.text: “slot machine” does not include a machine, apparatus, or device that:

subparagraph.text: awards the user only free additional games or plays;
awards the user only noncash merchandise or noncash prizes of minimal value;
dispenses paper pull tab tip jar tickets or paper pull tab instant bingo tickets that must be opened manually by the user provided that the machine, apparatus, or device does not:

sub-subparagraph.text: read the tickets electronically;
alert the user to a winning or losing ticket; or
tabulate a player’s winnings and losses;

is a handheld device that displays only facsimiles of bingo cards that an individual uses to mark and monitor contemporaneously to a live call of bingo numbers called on the premises by an individual where the user is operating the machine;
does not permit a user to play more than 54 bingo cards at the same time;
does not randomly generate any numbers; and
is not part of an integrated system;

subparagraph.text: is used by the State Lottery Commission under Title 9 of the State Government Article;
if legislation takes effect authorizing the operation of video lottery terminals, is a video lottery terminal as defined in and licensed under that legislation; or
is a skills–based amusement device that awards prizes of minimal value approved by the State Lottery Commission through regulation.

subsection.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection and consistent with the provisions of this title and Title 13 of this article, the Commission shall certify and regulate the operation, ownership, and manufacture of an electronic gaming device authorized under this title.
This section does not apply to:

subparagraph.text: the ownership or operation of slot machines that are subject to regulation by the Comptroller under § 12–304 of this title; and
paper tip jar gaming where authorized.
This paragraph applies only in Baltimore City and Baltimore County.

If a local law enforcement agency refuses to enforce a provision regarding the legal operation of amusement games, the Commission shall refer the matter to the appropriate office of the State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: The Commission shall adopt regulations that:

paragraph.text: define lawful and unlawful electronic and mechanical equipment used in connection with gaming devices that are consistent with this title;
approve and license electronic gaming devices authorized under State law;
approve and license owners, operators, and manufacturers of electronic gaming devices authorized under State law;
establish procedures for the license application and renewal processes required under this section; and
establish license fees that are sufficient to cover the direct and indirect costs of licensure required under this section.

subsection.text: The Commission may determine:

paragraph.text: that a county’s licensing and regulatory process for electronic gaming devices is equivalent to the State licensing and regulatory process required under this section; and
that a county license for owning, operating, or manufacturing an electronic gaming device in that county is equivalent to a State license.

subsection.text: An electronic gaming device that is not licensed or otherwise operated in compliance with the provisions of this section as of January 1, 2013, is an illegal gaming device that may not legally operate in the State.

Except as allowed under §§ 12-304 through 12-306 of this subtitle, a person may not locate, possess, keep, or operate a slot machine in the State as an owner, lessor, lessee, licensor, licensee, or in any other capacity.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine of $1,000 or both for each violation.
In this section, “antique slot machine” means a slot machine that was manufactured at least 25 years before the date on which the machine is seized.
A person may not be convicted under § 12-302 of this subtitle if the person shows by a preponderance of the evidence that the slot machine:

paragraph.text: is an antique slot machine; and
was not operated for gambling purposes while in the person’s possession.

subsection.text: If the defense is offered that a seized slot machine is an antique slot machine, the slot machine may not be destroyed or otherwise altered until after a final judicial determination, including review on appeal, that the defense does not apply.
If the defense applies, the person who seized the slot machine shall return the slot machine in accordance with applicable provisions of law for the return of property.
In this section, “eligible organization” means:

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization that:

subparagraph.text: has been located in a county listed in subsection (b) of this section for at least 5 years before the organization applies for a license under subsection (e) of this section; and
is a bona fide:

sub-subparagraph.text: fraternal organization;
religious organization; or
war veterans’ organization; or

paragraph.text: a nonprofit organization that has been affiliated with a national fraternal organization for less than 5 years and has been located in a county listed in subsection (b) of this section for at least 50 years before the nonprofit organization applies for a license under subsection (e) of this section.

subsection.text: This section applies in:

paragraph.text: Caroline County;
Cecil County;
Dorchester County;
Kent County;
Queen Anne’s County;
Somerset County;
Talbot County;
Wicomico County; and
Worcester County.
In this subsection, a console or set of affixed slot machines is not an individual slot machine.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, an eligible organization may own and operate a slot machine if the eligible organization:

subparagraph.text: obtains a license under subsection (e) of this section for each slot machine;
owns each slot machine that the eligible organization operates;
owns not more than five slot machines;
locates and operates its slot machines at its principal meeting hall in the county in which the eligible organization is located;
does not locate or operate its slot machines in a private commercial facility;
uses:

sub-subparagraph.text: at least one–half of the net after payout proceeds from its slot machines for the benefit of a charity; and
the remainder of the proceeds from its slot machines to further the purposes of the eligible organization;

subparagraph.text: does not use any of the proceeds of the slot machine for the financial benefit of an individual; and
reports annually under affidavit to the State Comptroller:

sub-subparagraph.text: the income of each slot machine; and
the disposition of the income from each slot machine.

subsection.text: An eligible organization may not use or operate a slot machine unless:

paragraph.text: the slot machine is equipped with a tamperproof meter or counter that accurately records gross receipts; and
the eligible organization keeps an accurate record of the gross receipts and payoffs of the slot machine.

subparagraph.text: The State Comptroller shall regulate the operation of slot machines under this section.

The State Comptroller may adopt regulations to implement the requirements of this section, including requiring audits of the annual reports submitted to the State Comptroller under subsection (c)(2)(viii) of this section.

paragraph.text: Before an eligible organization may operate a slot machine under this section, the eligible organization shall obtain a license for the slot machine from the State Comptroller.

subparagraph.text: The State Comptroller shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: charge an annual fee for each license for a machine; and
issue a license sticker to the applicant.

subparagraph.text: The applicant shall place the sticker on the slot machine.

The State Comptroller shall set the amount of the annual fee so that the total proceeds of the annual fee equal an amount directly related to administrative costs of the State Comptroller to regulate the operation of slot machines under this section.

paragraph.text: In the application to the State Comptroller for a license, one of the principal officers of the eligible organization shall certify under affidavit that the organization:

subparagraph.text: is an eligible organization; and
will comply with this section.

paragraph.text: A principal officer of the eligible organization may not intentionally misrepresent a statement of fact on the application.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of perjury and on conviction is subject to the penalty provided under Title 9, Subtitle 1 of this article.

subsection.text: The Comptroller may not issue a license for a slot machine to an eligible organization located in Ocean City that is located east of South and North Baltimore Avenues.
A person may take delivery of, possess, or transport a slot machine to demonstrate or sell the slot machine to a prospective customer who is allowed to purchase a slot machine if the person:

paragraph.text: operates with or under a distributorship contract with a manufacturer of slot machines;
is registered with the United States Department of Justice as a distributor of slot machines; and
has provided the Secretary of State Police with a copy of the person’s current federal registration.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine of $1,000 or both for each violation.
In this section, “premises” means an improved or unimproved parcel or tract of land that is owned by:

paragraph.text: a person; or
persons associated in a joint or common venture.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, in a county or municipal corporation where, before July 1, 1963, county or municipal officials licensed slot machines for operation, a person may not, as an owner, lessor, lessee, licensor, licensee, or in any other capacity, keep or operate a slot machine for any purpose in any place of business or building or on any premises.
Before disposing of a slot machine, the county commissioners or county executive of a county where a slot machine is located may require the slot machine to be:

subparagraph.text: registered in a manner appropriate to the office of county executive or county commissioners; and
sealed against use, stored, and kept under the supervision and control of the county commissioners or county executive.

subsection.text: Because of an act of God, or condemnation or abandonment of the primary business by the owner of a business operating on the premises, a person may:

paragraph.text: remove a slot machine from any premises on which a slot machine is allowed to operate under law; and
transfer the slot machine to another premises within the same county.

subsection.text: A person who transfers a slot machine from one premises to another may not increase the total number of machines allowed by law.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this subtitle, an entity licensed to offer instant bingo under a commercial bingo license on July 1, 2007, or by a qualified organization as defined in § 13–201 of this article on the premises of the qualified organization may continue to operate a game of instant bingo in the same manner using electronic machines, provided that:

subparagraph.text: the machines were in operation for a 1–year period ending December 31, 2007; or
the machines were in operation under a commercial bingo license on December 31, 2007;

paragraph.text: the entity does not operate more than the number of electronic machines in operation on February 28, 2008; and
the conduct of the gaming and operation of the machines are consistent with all other provisions of this article.

subsection.text: Activities conducted under this title are allowed notwithstanding the provisions of Title 12, Subtitles 1 and 2 of this article.
A county may not issue a commercial bingo license under this title or under any public local law to an entity that was not licensed to conduct commercial bingo on or before June 30, 2008.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, or raffle.
“Qualified organization” means:

paragraph.text: a volunteer fire company; or
a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization; or
charitable organization.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this title, this subtitle applies in the following counties:

paragraph.text: Allegany County;
Anne Arundel County;
Baltimore County;
Calvert County;
Caroline County;
Carroll County;
Dorchester County;
Frederick County;
Garrett County;
Howard County;
Prince George’s County;
St. Mary’s County;
Somerset County;
Talbot County; and
Washington County.

section.text: This title and Title 12 of this article do not prohibit a qualified organization from conducting a gaming event for the exclusive benefit of a qualified organization if an individual or group of individuals does not:

paragraph.text: benefit financially from the gaming event under this subtitle; or
receive any of the proceeds from the gaming event under this subtitle for personal use or benefit.

section.text: A qualified organization may award a prize in money or in merchandise at a gaming event using any gaming device, including:

paragraph.text: a paddle wheel;
a wheel of fortune;
a chance book; or
bingo.

section.text: A qualified organization that conducts a gaming event under this subtitle shall manage the gaming event personally through its members.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Allegany County.

paragraph.text: In this section, “paper gaming” means a game of chance in which:

subparagraph.text: prizes are awarded; and
the devices used to play the game are constructed out of paper or cardboard.

paragraph.text: “Paper gaming” includes tip jar and punchboard gaming.
“Paper gaming” does not include bingo.

subsection.text: This section applies only in Allegany County.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a person that is a for profit business or qualified organization may engage in paper gaming if the person obtains a paper gaming license that is issued by the Board of County Commissioners.
If the person is a for profit business, the person shall also hold a Class A, C, or D retail alcoholic beverages license.
Qualified organizations that do not have an alcoholic beverages license and fire and rescue departments may engage in paper gaming without obtaining a paper gaming license.

subsection.text: A person may sell paper gaming devices to a paper gaming licensee if the person obtains a wholesale vendor’s license issued by the Board of County Commissioners.
The Board of County Commissioners shall set annual fees for a paper gaming license and a wholesale vendor’s license.

Monthly, wholesale vendor licensees shall provide a list to the Board of County Commissioners of all customers to whom they sell paper gaming products and the total number of products sold to each customer.
A paper gaming licensee may not have on its premises a paper gaming device that does not display a gaming sticker.

The Board of County Commissioners shall ensure that each retail alcoholic beverages licensee who holds a paper gaming license sells to the public the same serial-numbered paper gaming devices that are listed on the bill of sale from the wholesale vendor licensee.

paragraph.text: The Board of County Commissioners may impose the following paper gaming taxes:

subparagraph.text: on licensees that are qualified organizations, 10% of gross profits minus the costs of paper gaming products; and
on licensees that are for profit businesses, 40% of gross profits minus the costs of paper gaming products.

paragraph.text: The Board of County Commissioners may not impose a paper gaming tax on qualified organizations that do not have an alcoholic beverages license or fire and rescue departments that buy paper gaming devices from a licensed wholesale vendor.
In this subsection, “Fund” means the Special Gaming Fund.
The Board of County Commissioners may establish a Special Gaming Fund.
The Fund is a special continuing, nonlapsing fund.
The Fund may be used only to benefit fire and rescue departments and to pay for specified school costs.

subparagraph.text: The Fund consists of:

sub-subparagraph.text: revenue derived from the taxation of gross profits from tip jar sales; and
subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, money received from other sources.

subparagraph.text: Money from the General Fund of the State or county, including any federal money, may not be transferred by budget amendment or otherwise to the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund shall be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other county funds.
Annually the Board of County Commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: pay from the Fund all administrative costs of carrying out this section, including the hiring of additional necessary personnel; and
allocate the remaining money in the Fund as follows:

sub-subparagraph.text: at least 25% but not more than 35% to fire and rescue departments; and
the balance to pay for school construction, school supplies, and other nonmaintenance of effort costs.

subsection.text: The Board of County Commissioners may adopt rules and regulations to administer and enforce this section.
The Board of County Commissioners may:

paragraph.text: hire one or more inspectors; and
authorize each inspector to enter the premises of a licensee to ensure compliance with this section or a rule or regulation adopted under this section.

subsection.text: The Board of County Commissioners may adopt an ordinance or resolution declaring that a violation of this section or a rule or regulation adopted under this section is:

paragraph.text: a civil infraction under Article 25B, § 13C of the Code; or
a misdemeanor punishable by a term of imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

subsection.text: After a hearing, if the Board of County Commissioners or a designee of the Board finds that a paper gaming licensee, a wholesale vendor licensee, or an agent of a licensee has violated this section or a rule or regulation adopted under this section, the Board may suspend or revoke the license in addition to any fine or penalty imposed under subsection (m) of this section.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Casino event” means any event that involves a card game, dice game, or roulette game.
“Casino event” does not include a card game or dice game that is played for tokens for which no cash prize is offered or awarded.

subsection.text: “Gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, raffle, or other organized gaming event.
This subtitle applies only in Anne Arundel County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Anne Arundel County.
“Qualified member” means a person who:

paragraph.text: obtained a membership in an organization in accordance with the charter and bylaws of the organization; and
has been a member for at least 12 months immediately before the gaming event.

subsection.text: A gaming device that is used at a gaming event shall be operated:

paragraph.text: by qualified members of the organization or qualified members of other organizations allowed to operate gaming devices under this section; and
without the assistance of professional gaming device operators.
A person may not receive compensation from an organization for managing or operating a gaming device at a gaming event.
Another organization that operates a gaming device under this subtitle may receive compensation from an organization for managing or operating a gaming device at a gaming event.

subsection.text: Each organization conducting a gaming event shall submit to the Department of Inspections and Permits, in a manner determined by the county, a report under oath for each gaming event that provides:

paragraph.text: an accounting of all funds received; and

a listing of the names, addresses, ages, and dates of membership of each individual who managed or operated a gaming device at the gaming event, including a statement that the individual is a qualified member of the organization.

subsection.text: This section may not be construed to:

paragraph.text: limit or restrict the authority of the county to regulate, license, and designate the type of amusement or gaming devices that may be operated in the county; or
amend or apply to the laws pertaining to raffles in the county under § 13-405 of this subtitle.

section.text: A person may not conduct a casino event in the county.

subsection.text: A bona fide fraternal, civic, war veterans’, or charitable organization, or a volunteer fire company may conduct a raffle in the county for the benefit of charity if:

paragraph.text: the raffle is conducted to further the purposes of the organization; and
no individual or group of individuals financially benefits from the holding of the raffle or receives any of the proceeds from the raffle for personal use.

subsection.text: Prizes may be awarded by the use of paddle wheels, wheels of fortune, or chance books.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a political committee, as defined in § 1-101 of the Election Law Article, may conduct a fundraiser at which prizes of merchandise or money are awarded in a game or spin using a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune.
A political committee may award a merchandise or money prize under this section that does not exceed the amount otherwise allowed for a prize in the county.
In this section, “bingo” includes the game of instant bingo.
A bona fide religious, fraternal, or charitable organization, or a volunteer fire company operating in a community that does not have a paid fire department, may conduct bingo in the county:

paragraph.text: for the benefit of charity in the county; or
to further the purposes of the organization.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly operate or attempt to operate a gaming event in the county in violation of § 13-403 or § 13-404 of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means the Baltimore City Police Commissioner.
“Gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, or raffle.
“Raffle” means one or more drawings from a single series of chances sold from chance books.

section.text: This subtitle applies only in Baltimore City.

subsection.text: Before an organization listed in subsection (b) of this section may operate a gaming event, the organization shall obtain a permit from the commissioner.

paragraph.text: An organization that meets the conditions of paragraph (2) of this subsection may conduct a gaming event for the benefit of any of the following listed organizations if the organization is a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
veterans’ hospital;
amateur athletic organization in which all playing members are under the age of 18 years; or
charitable organization.

paragraph.text: An organization conducting a gaming event shall:

subparagraph.text: be located in Baltimore City; and
spend a majority of the organization’s funds in Baltimore City for:

sub-subparagraph.text: fraternal purposes;
civic purposes;
purposes related to a veterans’ hospital;
purposes related to amateur athletics; or
charitable purposes.

paragraph.text: Before the commissioner may issue a permit, the commissioner shall review the character of the organization applying for the permit to ascertain that the organization meets the requirements of §§ 13-503 through 13-505 of this subtitle.
The commissioner shall make any application for a permit and the action taken by the commissioner on that application a matter of public record.
The permit shall state that the gaming event shall be managed and operated personally only by members of the organization obtaining the permit.
The permit is not transferable.

subsection.text: An organization conducting a gaming event in Baltimore City may not allow an individual or group of individuals to:

paragraph.text: benefit financially from the gaming event; or
receive any of the proceeds of the gaming event for personal use or benefit.

section.text: An organization conducting a gaming event may award a prize of money or merchandise to any individual in any amount in one game or spin using:

paragraph.text: a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune; or
a film of a horse race.

subsection.text: A permit holder may award prizes in merchandise and money in a raffle in any amount.
A permit holder may not conduct more than 12 raffles in a calendar year.

Notwithstanding any other provisions of this title or Title 12 of this article, a political committee as defined in § 1-101 of the Election Law Article may conduct a fundraiser at which prizes of merchandise or money are awarded in a game or spin using a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune.
A political committee may award a prize of merchandise or money at a fundraiser that does not exceed the amount otherwise allowed for a prize in Baltimore City.
This section and § 13-509 of this subtitle also apply to games of instant bingo.
Before an organization listed in subsection (c) or (d) of this section may conduct bingo in Baltimore City, the organization shall obtain a permit to do so from the commissioner.
An organization that meets the conditions of subsection (i)(1) of this section may conduct bingo in Baltimore City if the organization is a bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization; or
charitable organization.

subsection.text: An organization that meets the conditions of subsection (i)(2) of this section may conduct bingo in Baltimore City if the organization is:

paragraph.text: devoted exclusively to religious, charitable, or educational purposes;
a service organization;
a fraternal organization; or
a veterans’ organization.

Before the commissioner may issue a permit, the commissioner shall review the character of the organization applying for the permit to ascertain that the organization meets the requirements of this section.
The organization applying for the permit shall pay the permit fee set in subsection (g) of this section.
An application for a permit and the action taken by the commissioner on that application are public records.

subsection.text: The commissioner may issue a permit for:

paragraph.text: 1 day; or
a period exceeding 1 day and not exceeding 12 months.

subsection.text: Except as allowed under subsection (h)(1) of this section, the commissioner shall collect from each permit holder, to cover the costs of administering the Baltimore City bingo laws, a permit fee not exceeding:

paragraph.text: $10 for each day on which bingo may be conducted;
$750 for a 3-month period; or
$3,000 for a 12-month period.
The commissioner may collect a special annual permit fee of $5 for a nonprofit organization or nonprofit corporation to conduct, over 1 year, a number of bingo games for which, for each game:

subparagraph.text: the value of any prize of merchandise or money is not more than $5; and
not more than 100 individuals play.

paragraph.text: The commissioner may revoke a special annual permit for cause.
An organization conducting bingo in Baltimore City under subsection (c) of this section:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, may not offer or award, in any game:

sub-subparagraph.text: a money prize of more than $45; or
a prize of merchandise worth more than $45; and

subparagraph.text: after reimbursing any costs incurred in conducting bingo for personnel, supplies, equipment, and other expenses, shall use the entire proceeds for:

sub-subparagraph.text: charitable purposes; or
to further the purposes of an organization listed in subsection (c) of this section.

paragraph.text: An organization conducting bingo in Baltimore City under subsection (d) of this section:

subparagraph.text: may not use the net proceeds to benefit a stockholder or member of the organization;
after reimbursing any costs incurred in conducting bingo for personnel, supplies, equipment, and other expenses, shall use the net proceeds:

sub-subparagraph.text: solely for charitable purposes; or
to further the purposes of an organization listed in subsection (d) of this section; and

subparagraph.text: shall limit prizes of money or merchandise to a value not exceeding:

sub-subparagraph.text: $5,000 for the total of all prizes;
$75 for the total of all door prizes;
$45 for each of not more than five early bird games;
$75 for each of not more than 19 regular games;
$150 for the starting prize of one regular game with a jackpot, with nightly increases not exceeding $75 and a consolation prize not exceeding $75;
$150 for each of not more than four regular special games;
50% of the proceeds for each of not more than four split-the-pot games;
100% of the proceeds for not more than one winner-take-all game;
$3,000 for a jackpot game which starts at 50 numbers and adds one number every second night;
if the jackpot is not won, $375 for a consolation prize for any jackpot game;
$300 for the first jackpot game in a buildup jackpot game which starts at $300 and 50 numbers and adds one number and $75 each night; and
if the jackpot is not won, $225 for the consolation prize for any buildup jackpot game.

paragraph.text: A bingo permit holder issued a permit under either subsection (c) or (d) of this section may not conduct bingo:

subparagraph.text: in a restaurant or tavern where alcoholic beverages are sold;
in a permanent place of amusement or entertainment; or
on Sunday, except by a bona fide religious organization that conducts bingo on property owned or leased by the organization.

section.text: Notwithstanding § 13-507 of this subtitle, an organization may conduct bingo if:

paragraph.text: the membership of the organization consists only of individuals who are at least 60 years old;
the organization was formed primarily for social purposes;
all proceeds of the games of bingo are used only to further the purposes of the organization; and
the organization complies with the permit procedures and conditions imposed under § 13-507 of this subtitle.

section.text: The commissioner may adopt regulations reasonably necessary to administer § 13-507 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly conduct or attempt to conduct a bazaar or raffle in violation of §§ 13-503 through 13-505 of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, or raffle.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only in Baltimore County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Baltimore County to:

paragraph.text: except as provided in § 13-606 of this subtitle, bingo;
instant bingo;
a bona fide amateur athletic organization in which all playing members are under the age of 18 years;
a bona fide veterans’ hospital; and
a bona fide veterans’ organization.

subsection.text: Before an organization listed in subsection (b) of this section may operate a gaming event or casino event, the organization shall obtain a permit from the Department of Permits and Development Management.

paragraph.text: An organization that meets the conditions of paragraph (2) of this subsection may conduct a gaming event or casino event if the organization is a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a hunting organization;
a social organization; or
a sporting organization;

subparagraph.text: volunteer fire organization;
veterans’ organization;
veterans’ hospital;
amateur athletic organization; or
charitable organization.

paragraph.text: An organization that conducts a gaming event or casino event under this section shall spend a majority of the net proceeds from the gaming event or casino event for the following in the county:

subparagraph.text: purposes that benefit religious purposes;
fraternal purposes;
civic purposes;
volunteer fire operations;
purposes that benefit veterans;
purposes that benefit a veterans’ hospital;
purposes related to amateur athletics; or
charitable purposes.

paragraph.text: A permit to conduct a gaming event or casino event shall provide that only the members of the permit holder may manage the gaming event or casino event.
A permit is not transferable.
An organization that obtains a permit may award a prize of money or merchandise using:

subparagraph.text: a paddle wheel;
a wheel of fortune;
a chance book;
bingo; or
any other gaming device except:

sub-subparagraph.text: a card game;
a dice game; or
roulette.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in § 13-604 of this subtitle, a person may not:

subparagraph.text: operate a card game, a dice game, or roulette; or
conduct a casino event.

paragraph.text: An organization that obtains a permit shall ensure that:

subparagraph.text: an individual or group of individuals does not benefit financially from the holding of the gaming event;
an individual or group of individuals does not receive any of the proceeds of the gaming event for personal use or benefit; and
the gaming event is managed personally by the members of the permit holder.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (b) and (c) of this section, an organization may conduct:

paragraph.text: one casino event that includes a card game during each calendar month; and
one casino event that includes roulette during each calendar year.

subsection.text: To conduct a casino event under subsection (a) of this section, an organization shall be a bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization, including:

subparagraph.text: a hunting organization;
a social organization; or
a sporting organization;

paragraph.text: volunteer fire company;
war veterans’ organization; or
charitable organization.
A permit holder for a casino event that includes a card game or roulette shall ensure that:

subparagraph.text: the event is conducted in accordance with § 13-603(d)(3) of this subtitle;
a parent, subsidiary, or affiliate of the organization sponsoring the event has not sponsored a casino event within the calendar month; and
the casino event is conducted between 4 p.m. and 1 a.m.

paragraph.text: A person that holds a casino event that includes a card game or roulette may not:

subparagraph.text: offer or award a money prize to a player of the card game or roulette game;
allow a player to bet more than $10 in any one game within the calendar month;
exchange tokens used in wagering for an item of merchandise that is worth more than $1,000; or
exchange merchandise that was received for tokens that were used in wagering for:

sub-subparagraph.text: money; or
an item of merchandise having a value that is different from the fair retail market value of the item of merchandise that was received for the tokens.

subparagraph.text: Within 60 days after holding a casino event that includes a card game or roulette, the holder of the permit for the event shall submit to the Department of Permits and Development Management a financial report that lists the receipts and expenditures for the casino event.
Before the permit holder submits the report to the Department of Permits and Development Management, the permit holder shall submit the report to the county police department for review.

paragraph.text: The Department of Permits and Development Management shall adopt regulations to govern:

subparagraph.text: the issuing of a permit to conduct a casino event; and
the conduct and management of a casino event in a manner designed to prevent fraud and protect the public.

paragraph.text: The regulations shall require that a separate permit be issued for each casino event to be conducted.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a political committee, as defined in § 1-101 of the Election Law Article, may conduct a fundraiser at which prizes of money or merchandise are awarded in a game or spin using a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune.
A political committee may award a money or merchandise prize under this section if the prize does not exceed the amount otherwise allowed for a prize in the county.
Before an organization may conduct bingo in the county, the organization shall obtain a bingo license from the Department of Permits and Development Management.
An organization may conduct bingo to benefit charity in the county or to further its purposes if the organization is:

paragraph.text: a tax-supported volunteer fire company or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with a tax-supported volunteer fire company;
a nationally chartered veterans’ organization or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with a nationally chartered veterans’ organization;
a bona fide religious group that has conducted religious services at a fixed location in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a bingo license;
the Maryland State Fair and Agricultural Society;
a bona fide fraternal organization;
a bona fide patriotic organization; or
a bona fide charitable organization that has been located at a fixed location in the county for 3 years before applying for a bingo license.
An applicant for a bingo license shall apply for a license on the application form that the Department of Permits and Development Management provides.
The application shall include:

subparagraph.text: the name of the applicant;
the name and address of each officer and director of the applicant;
a complete statement of the purposes of the applicant;
a statement of the purpose for which the proceeds of the bingo operation will be used;
an affidavit that an agreement does not exist to divide any part of the proceeds of the bingo operation with any other person that is made by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the president;
the treasurer;
the chief executive; or
a fiscal officer;

subparagraph.text: an affidavit that only the applicant or a member of the applicant will receive any of the proceeds of the bingo operation except to further the purposes of the applicant organization; and
any other information the Department of Permits and Development Management requires.
An annual bingo license issued by the Department of Permits and Development Management authorizes the license holder to conduct bingo at the fixed location stated on the license:

sub-subparagraph.text: at any time during the year for which the license is issued; but
not more often than twice each week in the year for which the license is issued.

subparagraph.text: An applicant for an annual license shall pay the fee that the Department of Permits and Development Management sets.

A temporary license issued by the Department of Permits and Development Management authorizes the license holder to conduct bingo at the fixed location stated on the license for not more than 10 days in the year for which the license is issued.
An applicant for a temporary license shall pay the fee that the administrative officer of the county sets.

A 1-day license issued by the Department of Permits and Development Management authorizes the license holder to conduct bingo at a fixed location stated on the license for not more than 1 day in the year for which the license is issued.
An applicant for a 1-day license shall pay a fee that the administrative officer of the county sets.
The Department of Permits and Development Management may not grant an applicant more than three 1-day licenses in any calendar year.

paragraph.text: The Department of Permits and Development Management may require the holder of a bingo license to produce its financial records for inspection so that the Department may ensure that the license holder and the members of the license holder have complied with subsection (c)(2)(v) and (vi) of this section.
A person may not conduct bingo on Sunday.

subsection.text: The Department of Permits and Development Management shall deposit the fees paid for bingo licenses issued under this section in the county Widows’ Pension Fund.

After a public hearing, the Department of Permits and Development Management may revoke the license of a license holder that fails to comply with this section or the regulations that the Department adopts under this section.
The Department of Permits and Development Management may adopt regulations to govern:

paragraph.text: the conduct of bingo;
the amounts of the prizes that may be awarded in a game of bingo;
the method of awarding prizes;
the hours that bingo may be conducted; and
any other matters related to the proper conduct of bingo.

subparagraph.text: A person may not divert or pay any proceeds of bingo conducted under a bingo license to:

sub-subparagraph.text: any other person, except to a member of the license holder; or
any other partnership or corporation, except to further the purposes of the license holder.

subparagraph.text: A person who is not a member of a license holder may not receive any of the proceeds of bingo conducted under a bingo license except to further the purposes of the license holder.
A person may not violate a regulation that the Department of Permits and Development Management adopts under subsection (h) of this section.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly conduct or attempt to conduct a gaming event or casino event in violation of §§ 13-603 through 13-605 of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Committee” means the Gambling Permit Review Committee appointed by the county commissioners under § 13-704 of this subtitle.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Calvert County.
“Gaming event” includes a carnival and a bazaar.
This subtitle applies only in Calvert County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Calvert County.
Before an organization may conduct a gaming event, the organization shall obtain a permit from the county commissioners.
An organization may conduct a gaming event in the county if the organization is:

paragraph.text: a volunteer fire company; or
a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization; or
charitable organization.

paragraph.text: The permit shall state:

subparagraph.text: the nature of any gaming device to be operated at the gaming event; and
the frequency with which the gaming event will be conducted.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may charge a reasonable fee for a permit.
The county commissioners shall appoint a Gambling Permit Review Committee.
The committee consists of five regular members and two alternate members.
A quorum of the committee consists of:

subparagraph.text: three regular members; or
if fewer than three regular members are present at a meeting, enough alternate members designated by the chairperson to act as regular members to create a quorum.

paragraph.text: An alternate member of the committee may serve only as provided under paragraph (3) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Subject to the approval of the county commissioners, the committee shall adopt regulations to govern gambling activities and the issuance of permits under § 13-703 of this subtitle.
For purposes of this section, a game of instant bingo conducted under a Class NG beach license is considered to be bingo.
Before a person may conduct bingo in the county, the person shall obtain a license from the county commissioners.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a person who complies with this section may conduct bingo in the county.

subparagraph.text: The county commissioners may not issue a license unless the application was filed at least 30 days before the date of issuance.
An applicant for a license shall:

sub-subparagraph.text: file an application on a form that the county commissioners provide; and
sign the application under oath.

subparagraph.text: The application shall include:

sub-subparagraph.text: the name of the applicant;
the address of the applicant;
any trade name of the applicant;
if the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each partner;
if the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of each officer of the corporation;
if a resident agent is required under paragraph (3) of this subsection, the name and address of the applicant’s resident agent;
the name and address of any person having a financial interest in the operation of the proposed bingo; and
the signatures of all of the individuals listed in items 1 through 7 of this subparagraph indicating consent to individual liability for any unlawful operation of licensed bingo.
The county commissioners may refuse to issue a license based on the facts disclosed on an application.
Subparagraph (i) of this paragraph does not require the county commissioners to investigate an applicant’s statements on the application before issuing a license.

paragraph.text: Each applicant for a license shall present evidence to the county commissioners that the applicant has obtained a public liability insurance policy that:

subparagraph.text: covers the period covered by the proposed license;
provides coverage for personal injury to:

sub-subparagraph.text: any bingo patron in an amount not less than $100,000; and
more than one bingo patron in an amount not less than $500,000.

subparagraph.text: Each nonresident applicant for a license shall designate a resident agent.
A resident agent must be:

sub-subparagraph.text: a voter in the county;
a taxpayer of the county; and
an owner of property in the county assessed at not less than $25,000.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may issue the following licenses:

subparagraph.text: a Class NA license, for bingo that does not exceed a seating or player capacity of 750 individuals;
a Class NB license, for bingo that does not exceed a seating or player capacity of 500 individuals;
a Class NC license, for bingo that does not exceed a seating or player capacity of 1,000 individuals;
a Class ND beach license, for bingo that:

sub-subparagraph.text: does not exceed a seating or player capacity of 500 individuals;
may be operated within the town limits of North Beach or Chesapeake Beach; and
may be operated between May 1 and September 30;

subparagraph.text: a Class NE beach license, for bingo that:

sub-subparagraph.text: does not exceed a seating or player capacity of 1,000 individuals;
may be operated within the town limits of North Beach or Chesapeake Beach; and
may be operated between May 1 and September 30;

subparagraph.text: a Class NF beach license, for bingo that:

sub-subparagraph.text: does not exceed a seating or player capacity of 500 individuals;
may be operated within the town limits of North Beach or Chesapeake Beach; and
may be operated throughout the year; or

subparagraph.text: a Class NG beach license, for bingo that:

sub-subparagraph.text: does not have a limitation on seating or player capacity;
may be operated within the town limits of North Beach or Chesapeake Beach; and
may be operated throughout the year.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: retain a copy of each license issued;
issue a copy of the license to the license holder; and
forward a copy of the license to the State Comptroller.

paragraph.text: A license is not transferable.

subsection.text: The county commissioners shall assess the following annual license fees:

paragraph.text: $3,500 for a Class NA license;
$3,000 for a Class NB license;
$4,000 for a Class NC license;
$500 for a Class ND beach license;
$1,000 for a Class NE beach license;
$3,000 for a Class NF beach license; and
$5,000 for a Class NG beach license.
The county commissioners may not issue a license if the conduct of bingo would:

subparagraph.text: unduly disturb the peace of the neighborhood in which the applicant proposes to conduct bingo;
create a nuisance; or
be detrimental to the health or welfare of the community.
The county commissioners may not issue a license to conduct bingo in a building that is not permanent and covered by a roof.
This paragraph does not apply to a person who is not required to obtain a license to conduct bingo.
The following licenses may not allow the conduct of bingo on Sunday:

sub-subparagraph.text: a Class NA license;
a Class NB license; or
a Class NC license.

subparagraph.text: The following licenses may not allow the conduct of bingo before 1 p.m. on Sunday:

sub-subparagraph.text: a Class ND beach license;
a Class NE beach license; or
a Class NF beach license.

subparagraph.text: A Class NG beach license may not allow the conduct of bingo between 2 a.m. and 1 p.m. on Sunday.

section.text: The following organizations are not required to obtain a license under § 13-705 of this subtitle to conduct bingo:

paragraph.text: a religious organization;
a patriotic organization;
an educational organization;
a charitable or benevolent organization;
a civic organization;
a volunteer fire company; or
any other organization that is authorized under § 13-703 of this subtitle and Subtitle 2 of this title to conduct bingo in the county.

subsection.text: A license holder may issue as a prize or award to the patron of licensed bingo:

paragraph.text: merchandise;
money;
a token or ticket redeemable for money or merchandise; or
any other thing of value.
Except as provided under paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a license holder may not issue for one game a prize or award with a value exceeding $100.
A holder of a Class NG beach license may issue for one game a prize with a value exceeding $100.
A license holder may issue once each day:

subparagraph.text: a grand prize not exceeding $1,500; and
a grand prize not exceeding $3,000 in retail value.

section.text: In addition to any other penalty provided by law, the county commissioners may revoke a bingo license forthwith if:

paragraph.text: the county commissioners determine after an investigation that:

subparagraph.text: the license holder made a false statement in the application for the license; or
the conduct of licensed bingo at the premises named in the license would:

sub-subparagraph.text: disturb the peace of the neighborhood;
create a nuisance; or
be detrimental to the morals, health, or welfare of the community; or

paragraph.text: the license holder is convicted of:

subparagraph.text: violating §§ 13-705 through 13-707 of this subtitle; or
a felony.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may adopt regulations to govern:

paragraph.text: the conduct or play of bingo;
the issuance of bingo licenses;
the setting of fees for bingo licenses; and
the determination of the election districts and precincts in which bingo may be conducted.

subsection.text: In adopting regulations, the county commissioners shall ensure uniform application as to:

paragraph.text: the determination of the districts and precincts in which bingo may be conducted; and
the setting of fees.

section.text: Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Caroline County.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Carroll County.
“Gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, raffle, or other game of entertainment.
This subtitle applies only in Carroll County.
Subject to this subtitle, Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Carroll County.
Before an organization may conduct a gaming event, the organization shall obtain a permit from the county commissioners.
To conduct bingo or a gaming event an organization must be a bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
hospital;
amateur athletic organization;
charitable organization; or
volunteer fire company.
Before the county commissioners issue a permit, they shall determine whether the organization applying for the permit qualifies under this subtitle and the conditions of this subtitle are met.
An application for a permit and the action taken by the county commissioners on that application are public records.
The permit shall state that the gaming event shall be managed and operated only by members of the organization holding the permit.
A permit is not transferable.
A gaming event conducted under this section shall be conducted for the benefit of an organization listed in subsection (b) of this section.
An individual or group of individuals may not benefit financially, or receive proceeds for personal use or benefit, from a gaming event conducted under this section.
A permit may not authorize the operation of a gaming event after 1 a.m. on Sunday.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraphs (ii) and (iv) of this paragraph, an organization conducting a gaming event may award a money prize not exceeding $100 or merchandise not exceeding $100 of value to any individual in any one game.
The maximum amount of a prize awarded in a raffle is governed by § 13-904(c) of this subtitle.
The maximum amount of a prize awarded in a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune game is governed by § 13-905(a) of this subtitle.
The maximum amount of a prize awarded in bingo is governed by § 13-908 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Multi-drawing raffle” means a raffle for which the drawings are held on more than 1 day.
“Raffle” means one or more drawings using a single series of chances sold in chance books or similar devices, at which one or more prizes are awarded.
“Single-drawing raffle” means a raffle for which the drawings are held on a single day.

subsection.text: At a gaming event, the holder of a raffle may award a prize of money or merchandise using a chance book.

paragraph.text: A single-drawing raffle may have only one major prize.
During a year, an organization listed in § 13-903 of this subtitle may hold not more than:

subparagraph.text: six single-drawing raffles in which the major prize is worth $2,500 or more; or
ten single-drawing raffles in which the major prize is worth less than $2,500.

paragraph.text: An organization listed in § 13-903 of this subtitle may not hold:

subparagraph.text: more than 30 weekly drawings in a multi-drawing raffle;
more than two multi-drawing raffles during a year; or
a multi-drawing raffle in which the major prize is worth more than $1,100.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding § 13-903 of this subtitle, an organization listed in § 13-903 of this subtitle that operates a paddle wheel or wheel of fortune game at a gaming event may not award a prize to a person in any one game or spin of the wheel of:

subparagraph.text: money that exceeds $10; or
merchandise with a value that exceeds $250.

paragraph.text: An organization listed in § 13-903 of this subtitle may not hold more than 10 days of paddle-wheel games in a calendar year.

subsection.text: An organization listed in § 13-903 or § 13-907 of this subtitle may award a prize of money or merchandise using a gaming device other than a card game, dice game, or roulette.
A senior center site council may conduct billiards in a senior center 5 days per week, excluding Sunday.
A senior center site council may not award a prize of money to a winner exceeding $5 in each session.

paragraph.text: A senior center site council may conduct a billiards tournament with a maximum entry fee of $2 for each participant.
Prizes of money may be awarded to first, second, and third place winners from the entry fee money collected.
All money that remains after prizes are awarded shall be distributed to the senior center site council.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding § 13-903 of this subtitle, a person may not conduct a card game, dice game, roulette, or casino night unless the person is a senior center site council that conducts a card game under subsection (b) of this section.

paragraph.text: A senior center site council may conduct a card game in a senior center 5 days per week, excluding Sunday.
A senior center site council may not:

subparagraph.text: award a prize of money exceeding $5 to a winner in each session; and
charge a participant more than $1 to play one session.

paragraph.text: All money that remains after prizes are awarded shall be distributed to the senior center site council.

subsection.text: Before an organization may conduct bingo under this subtitle, the organization shall obtain a permit from the county commissioners.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “qualified organization” means a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization;
charitable organization;
volunteer fire company; or
senior center site council.

paragraph.text: A qualified organization may conduct bingo in the county to benefit charity or to further the purpose of the qualified organization.
A senior center site council may obtain a permit to conduct bingo in a senior center 5 days per week, excluding Sunday.
A senior center site council may not:

subparagraph.text: award a prize of money to a winner exceeding $50 in each session; or
charge more than 5 cents for each bingo card.

paragraph.text: All money that remains after prizes are awarded shall be distributed to the senior center site council.
An applicant for a permit shall pay the fee that the county commissioners set.
The county commissioners shall set the permit fee at a level sufficient to cover the costs of issuing the permit.
Only the holder of a permit issued under this section may conduct bingo authorized by the permit.
The holder of a permit issued under this section may not transfer or assign the right to conduct bingo to another person.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section and § 13-907(c)(2)(i) of this subtitle, a permit holder may not award a money prize greater than:

paragraph.text: $100 to a player of a regular bingo game; or
$250 to a player of a special bingo game, such as a build-up or progressive pot game, split-the-pot game, or winner-take-all game.

subsection.text: A permit holder may award a jackpot not exceeding $1,000 if the jackpot is directly connected with the playing of bingo.
A person may not knowingly operate or attempt to operate a gaming event in violation of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following terms have the meanings indicated.
“Bingo” includes instant bingo.
“Gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, raffle, or other game of entertainment.
“Qualified organization” means:

paragraph.text: a volunteer fire company; or
a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization; or
charitable organization.

section.text: This subtitle applies only in Cecil County.
A qualified organization may conduct bingo or a gaming event for the exclusive benefit of any qualified organization if an individual or group of individuals does not:

paragraph.text: benefit financially; or
receive proceeds of the bingo or gaming event for personal use or benefit.

section.text: A qualified organization may award a prize of money or merchandise at bingo or a gaming event through a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, chance book, or bingo.
The bingo or gaming event shall be managed personally by members of the qualified organization conducting the event.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Charles County Gaming Permit Review Board.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Charles County.
“Fundraising organization” means an incorporated or unincorporated bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
charitable organization;
volunteer fire company;
rescue squad; or
ambulance company.
“Gaming device” means a mechanism for playing a game of chance.
“Gaming device” includes a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, and chance book.
“Gaming device” does not include bingo, a slot machine, or other gaming device that is otherwise regulated by State law.
“Gaming event” means an event involving a game of chance.
“Gaming event” includes:

subparagraph.text: a carnival;
a bazaar; and
a raffle involving prizes of cash exceeding $1,000 or merchandise with a cash equivalent exceeding $1,000.

paragraph.text: “Gaming event” does not include bingo.

subsection.text: “Gaming permit” means a permit to operate a gaming device at a gaming event that the county commissioners issue under this subtitle.
“Person” includes a joint interest held by two or more persons.

“Representative” means a person who has been a bona fide member of a fundraising organization or educational organization for at least 1 year before the date of a gaming permit application by the fundraising organization or educational organization.

section.text: This subtitle applies to bingo and gaming events in Charles County.
The county commissioners may:

paragraph.text: designate the types of gaming devices that may be operated in the county;
set fees for gaming permits issued under this subtitle;
set salaries and funding for the board and the board’s clerk, legal counsel, and support staff;
approve or deny gaming permit applications;
investigate persons involved in gaming events and examine records of fundraising organizations with respect to gaming events;
delegate its powers and duties under this subtitle to the board; and
adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: There is a Charles County Gaming Permit Review Board.

paragraph.text: The board consists of seven members.
Of the seven members of the board:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a member of the county sheriff’s office;
one shall be a member of the Department of State Police;
one shall be a member of a fundraising organization in the county;
one shall be an individual with background and experience in finance; and
three shall be members at large.

paragraph.text: Each member at large:

subparagraph.text: shall be a member of the general public;
may not be a member of a fundraising organization or otherwise be subject to regulation by the board;
may not, within 1 year before appointment, have had a financial interest in or have received compensation from a person regulated by the board; and
may not, while a member of the board, have a financial interest in or receive compensation from a person regulated by the board.

paragraph.text: Each member of the board shall be a resident of the county.
The board shall select a chairperson from among its members, to serve the term that the board sets.
The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the board on October 1, 2002.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The board may recommend to the county commissioners:

paragraph.text: the types of gaming devices that may be operated in the county;
approval or denial of a gaming permit; and
modifications of the county gaming regulations and procedures.

subsection.text: The board shall:

paragraph.text: review at least quarterly gaming permit applications;
review gaming regulations and permit procedures;
keep a list of all approved lessors of gaming devices and premises for gaming events;
keep a record of the gaming permits that the board has reviewed; and
undertake the other duties regarding gaming regulation that the county commissioners delegate.

subsection.text: As the county commissioners consider appropriate, the county commissioners shall provide for the board a clerk, legal counsel, supplies, and funding.
The county commissioners may pay salaries to the members of the board.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a person may not conduct bingo or a gaming event in the county.

subsection.text: A gaming event may be conducted only by a fundraising organization that has been located in the county for at least 5 years before applying for a gaming permit.
A fundraising organization shall obtain a gaming permit for each gaming event that the fundraising organization conducts.

paragraph.text: At least 30 days before the first day of the calendar quarter in which the gaming event is to be conducted, a fundraising organization seeking a gaming permit shall submit to the board an application and the application fee.
The application shall contain the following:

subparagraph.text: the name of the fundraising organization;
a statement that the fundraising organization qualifies to conduct a gaming event under this subtitle;
the dates, times, and location of the gaming event;
the name, address, and telephone number of the representative responsible for the gaming event;
a roster of the current membership of the fundraising organization that includes names, ages, and addresses;
a statement that:

sub-subparagraph.text: an agreement does not exist for sharing the proceeds of the gaming event with any other person; and
no person other than the fundraising organization or its representative may receive any proceeds of the gaming event except to further the purposes of the fundraising organization; and

subparagraph.text: any other information that the board considers necessary or helpful.

paragraph.text: A principal officer of the fundraising organization shall sign and verify the application under the penalties of perjury.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may set a reasonable application fee for a gaming permit.

paragraph.text: The board shall:

subparagraph.text: review the gaming permit applications for a calendar quarter within 10 days after the application deadline set in subsection (c)(1) of this section;
recommend approval or denial of each application; and
promptly forward the applications and recommendations to the county commissioners.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: review the applications and recommendations;
approve or disapprove each application within 15 days after the application deadline set in subsection (c)(1) of this section;
promptly notify each applicant of the county commissioners’ action on the application; and
issue a gaming permit for each approved application.

paragraph.text: This section does not prevent the board or the county commissioners from reviewing gaming permit applications more frequently or earlier than required by this subsection.

section.text: The gaming permit shall include:

paragraph.text: the name of the fundraising organization;
the nature of the approved gaming event;
the dates, times, and location of the approved gaming event;
the gaming devices to be operated at the gaming event; and
the name of the representative responsible for the approved gaming event.
A gaming event may be conducted only in accordance with this subtitle.
A gaming device may only be managed or operated by a representative of the fundraising organization named in the gaming permit for the gaming event.
A professional gaming operator may not manage, operate, or assist in the management or operation of a gaming device.
A person may not receive any commission, salary, reward, tip, or other compensation for managing or operating a gaming device at a gaming event.
A minor may not participate in a gaming event.
A fundraising organization may lease gaming devices or premises for a gaming event only from a fundraising organization that the board approves.

subparagraph.text: A lease agreement of gaming devices or premises for a gaming event shall be priced on the basis of fair market value of the equipment or premises.
A lease agreement may not include a provision for sharing profit from a gaming event with a lessor or a provision that reasonably may be interpreted to provide for sharing profit from a gaming event.

paragraph.text: A fundraising organization may not conduct more than three gaming events during a calendar quarter.

subparagraph.text: A fundraising organization may not conduct a gaming event under a single gaming permit for a period greater than 48 hours.
The actual gaming time may not exceed 24 hours in that 48-hour period, which may be divided into not more than two separate gaming periods.

Notwithstanding subparagraph (i) of this paragraph, a fundraising organization that conducts a gaming event at the Charles County Fair in conjunction with the Charles County Fair Board may conduct the gaming event under a single gaming permit for more than 48 hours, subject to regulations that the county commissioners adopt on recommendation of the board.

paragraph.text: A fundraising organization that has conducted a gaming event shall submit a report to the board within 30 days after the end of the calendar quarter in which the gaming event was conducted.
The report shall contain:

subparagraph.text: the name of the fundraising organization;
the number of the gaming permit;
the date of the gaming event;
the date, amount, nature, source, and recipient of each receipt and expenditure associated with the gaming event, in the format that the board prescribes;
a separate list of the date, amount, and recipient of each charitable donation from the proceeds;
the name, age, address, and date of membership of each representative who managed, operated, or assisted in the operation or management of a gaming device at the gaming event;
a statement that each listed representative qualified as a representative under § 13-1101(i) of this subtitle at the time of the gaming event;
a statement that:

sub-subparagraph.text: an agreement does not exist and has not existed for sharing the proceeds of a gaming event with any other person; and
