only the fundraising organization or its representative has received or will receive any proceeds of the gaming event, except to further the purposes of the fundraising organization; and

subparagraph.text: any other information that the board considers necessary or helpful.

paragraph.text: A principal officer of the fundraising organization shall sign and verify the report under the penalties of perjury.

subsection.text: A fundraising organization that conducts a gaming event shall maintain accurate records of each transaction concerning the gaming event, and shall keep the records available for examination by the board and the county commissioners for 3 years after the gaming event.
A fundraising organization or educational organization may conduct bingo either for the benefit of charity in the county or to further the purposes of the organization.
Subject to subsection (c) of this section, a fundraising organization or educational organization may award money or merchandise as a prize in a bingo game.

paragraph.text: A fundraising organization or educational organization may not award a money prize exceeding $5,000 to any player in a bingo game.
A fundraising organization or educational organization may not award more than $10,000 in total money prizes in a single day.

subsection.text: A fundraising organization or educational organization may not conduct bingo at one location for more than 4 hours per day for:

paragraph.text: 4 days in a 7-day period; or
3 consecutive days.

section.text: A fundraising organization or educational organization may only allow its representatives to manage or operate bingo or gaming devices at its bingo or gaming event.
Proceeds of bingo or a gaming event may not:

paragraph.text: benefit a person other than the fundraising organization or educational organization that conducts the bingo or gaming event; or
be shared with a person other than the fundraising organization or educational organization, except to further the purposes of the fundraising organization or educational organization.

section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, a fundraising organization or educational organization may donate part of the proceeds of bingo or a gaming event at the Charles County Fair to the Charles County Fair Board.
A person who violates this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
In addition to any other penalty, a person who violates this subtitle is ineligible to obtain a gaming permit for 3 years after the date of the violation.

This subtitle does not restrict the authority of the county commissioners to adopt regulations on amusements and entertainments under Chapter 4 of the Code of Public Local Laws of Charles County or other State law.
In this subtitle, “gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, or raffle.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only in Dorchester County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Dorchester County.
A person must have a license for each day that the person conducts bingo unless the bingo is conducted in a licensed gaming event.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle or Subtitle 2 of this title, in addition to bingo conducted in connection with a gaming event under Subtitle 2 of this title, the clerk of the circuit court of the county may issue a license to conduct bingo.
To qualify for a license to conduct bingo, an applicant shall be a:

paragraph.text: bona fide religious group that has conducted religious services at a fixed location in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a license;
tax-supported volunteer fire company or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the fire company;
nationally chartered veterans’ organization or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the organization; or
nonprofit organization that:

subparagraph.text: intends to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose that is described in the application for a license; and
has operated in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a license.

subsection.text: An application for a license to conduct bingo shall contain a certification, by a principal officer of the applicant, stating:

paragraph.text: the time and place of the activities for which the license is sought;
that the bingo will be conducted and managed solely and personally by the regular members of the applicant without the assistance of gaming professionals; and
that no compensation or reward will be paid to any person for conducting or assisting in the conducting of the bingo.

subsection.text: A license issued under this subtitle may not authorize a game or carnival on a Sunday.
An individual under the age of 16 years may not be allowed to play, conduct, or operate bingo.

section.text: This subtitle does not authorize the use of a slot machine or coin machine for gambling purposes.
The bailiffs, municipal police officers, prosecuting officials, and other peace officers of the county shall enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: The clerk of the circuit court of the county shall collect $5 for a license for a raffle or carnival.
The clerk of the circuit court shall collect $25 from an applicant for an annual bingo license to conduct bingo and $1 for issuance of the license.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a 1-day bingo license is required for each day a bingo game is conducted.
The clerk of the circuit court of the county shall collect $1 for a 1-day bingo license.
A 1-day bingo license is not required for bingo conducted at a licensed carnival or under an annual bingo license.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Frederick County.
“Gaming event” includes a:

paragraph.text: bazaar;
carnival;
raffle;
tip jar; and
punchboard.

section.text: This subtitle applies only in Frederick County.

subsection.text: Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Frederick County.
A gaming event under Subtitle 2 of this title is subject to the requirements of this subtitle.
In addition to the qualified organizations listed in Subtitle 2 of this title, the following organizations and their auxiliaries may conduct activities governed by that subtitle:

paragraph.text: a volunteer fire company;
a volunteer rescue company; and
a volunteer ambulance company.

subsection.text: Subtitle 2 of this title also regulates any gaming device, including a:

paragraph.text: chance book;
tip jar;
paddle wheel; and
wheel of fortune.

subsection.text: Before an organization listed in subsection (b) of this section may conduct a gaming event, the organization shall obtain a permit from the county agency that the county commissioners designate.
An organization may conduct a gaming event for its own benefit if the organization is:

paragraph.text: a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
hospital;
amateur athletic organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization; or
charitable organization;

paragraph.text: a Frederick County volunteer:

subparagraph.text: fire company;
rescue company; or
ambulance company; or

paragraph.text: an auxiliary for a Frederick County volunteer:

subparagraph.text: fire company;
rescue company; or
ambulance company.

paragraph.text: Before the county agency may issue a gaming permit, the county agency shall determine whether the organization applying for the gaming permit meets the requirements of this section.
An application and the action that the county agency takes on the application are public records.

subparagraph.text: A gaming permit is valid for 1 year after the date that it is issued.
A gaming permit may not be transferred.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may charge a permit fee.
Only members of an organization that holds a gaming permit may conduct the gaming event.
Except as allowed under § 13-1305 of this subtitle, an individual may not benefit financially from a gaming event.
A gaming permit may not authorize a gaming event to be conducted on a Sunday before 1 p.m.
The holder of a gaming permit may award:

subparagraph.text: prizes to individuals at a gaming event; and
only one major prize at each gaming event.

paragraph.text: During each calendar year, the holder of a gaming event, including a raffle for which the prize drawings are held on a single day, may not hold or receive the proceeds from:

subparagraph.text: more than one gaming event in which the major prize has a value of more than $5,000; and
more than five raffles for which the prize drawings are held on a single day and in which the major prize has a value of $5,000 or less.

paragraph.text: During each calendar year, the holder of a gaming event may hold one raffle in which prize drawings are held on more than a single day if the major prize has a value of $5,000 or less.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this section and §§ 13-1305 and 13-1307 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: To operate a tip jar or punchboard in the county, an establishment or proprietor must be licensed to serve food and alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises.
The operator of a tip jar shall display conspicuously a gaming permit issued to the beneficiary of the tip jar under § 13-1304 of this subtitle.
The operator of a punchboard shall display within the establishment a gaming permit issued to the beneficiary of the punchboard under § 13-1304 of this subtitle.
A person may operate a tip jar or punchboard in the county only for the benefit of one of the following organizations located in the county:

subparagraph.text: a bona fide:

sub-subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
hospital;
amateur athletic organization;
patriotic organization;
charitable organization; or
educational organization;

subparagraph.text: a Frederick County volunteer:

sub-subparagraph.text: fire company;
rescue company; or
ambulance company; or

subparagraph.text: an auxiliary of a Frederick County volunteer:

sub-subparagraph.text: fire company;
rescue company; or
ambulance company.

paragraph.text: The beneficiary of a tip jar may not hold more than three permits to operate tip jars or punchboards outside of the beneficiary’s premises.

The beneficiary of a tip jar or punchboard must receive at least 70% of the gross proceeds of the tip jar or punchboard after paying winning players and reimbursing the operator for operating expenses.
For each tip jar or punchboard operated, the operator shall submit to the county agency that issued the gaming permit monthly reports detailing:

subparagraph.text: gross proceeds;
prizes;
expenses; and
the amount paid to the beneficiary.

subsection.text: The tip jar or punchboard shall be purchased from a distributor that:

paragraph.text: has an office in the State;
is licensed by the county agency that issues gaming event permits; and
keeps the records that the county commissioners require.

subsection.text: A person who keeps records about tip jars or punchboards shall make those records available for inspection and copying by a law enforcement unit or by the county agency that issues the gaming event permit.
A person authorized to conduct bingo under this subtitle shall obtain a bingo permit from the county agency designated by the county commissioners to issue a bingo permit.
Any of the following organizations, if a legal resident of the county, may conduct bingo to benefit charity in the county or to further the purposes of one of the following organizations:

paragraph.text: a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
hospital;
amateur athletic organization; or
charitable organization;

paragraph.text: a volunteer:

subparagraph.text: fire company;
rescue company; or
ambulance company; or

paragraph.text: an auxiliary for a volunteer:

subparagraph.text: fire company;
rescue company; or
ambulance company.

paragraph.text: A person who is not a legal resident of Frederick County may not conduct bingo.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, each year the Frederick County Agricultural Association may sell or lease a right or concession to any person to conduct bingo at the Frederick County Fair.
To qualify for a bingo permit, a person shall meet the requirements set by the county commissioners.
The county commissioners may require an applicant for a bingo permit to pay a permit fee set by the county commissioners.

subsection.text: A person who conducts bingo may not offer or award:

paragraph.text: a prize or award with a fair market value exceeding $5,000; or
a money prize exceeding $5,000.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this section.
A person may not knowingly violate § 13-1304 or § 13-1305 of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County Commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Garrett County.
“Gaming event” includes a bazaar, carnival, raffle, tip jar, punchboard, and any other event at which a gaming device is operated.

paragraph.text: “Gaming device” means:

subparagraph.text: except for a billiard table, a gaming table at which a game of chance is played for money or any other thing or consideration of value; or
a game or device at which money or any other thing or consideration of value is bet, wagered, or gambled.

paragraph.text: “Gaming device” includes a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, and chance book.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only in Garrett County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Garrett County.
Before an organization listed in subsection (b) of this section may conduct a gaming event, the organization shall obtain a permit from the county agency that the County Commissioners designate.
An organization may conduct a gaming event for its own benefit if the organization is:

paragraph.text: a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
hospital;
amateur athletic organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization; or
charitable organization;

paragraph.text: a county volunteer fire department or rescue squad; or
an auxiliary for a county volunteer fire department or rescue squad.
Before the county agency may issue a gaming permit, the county agency shall determine whether the organization applying for the gaming permit meets the requirements of this section.
An application and the action that the county agency takes on the application are public records.

subparagraph.text: A gaming permit is valid for 1 year after the date that it is issued.
A gaming permit may not be transferred.

paragraph.text: The County Commissioners may charge a permit fee.
Only members of an organization that holds a gaming permit may conduct a gaming event.
Except as allowed under § 13-1405 of this subtitle, an individual may not benefit financially from a gaming event.
A gaming permit may not authorize a gaming event to be conducted on a Sunday before 1 p.m.

subsection.text: The holder of a gaming permit may award:

paragraph.text: prizes to individuals at a gaming event; and
only one major prize at each gaming event.
In this section, “paper gaming” means a game of chance in which:

subparagraph.text: prizes are awarded; and
the devices used to play the game are constructed out of paper or cardboard.

paragraph.text: “Paper gaming” includes tip jar and punchboard gaming.
“Paper gaming” does not include bingo.

Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, a person that is a for profit business or an organization listed under § 13-1403(b) of this subtitle may engage in paper gaming if the person obtains a paper gaming license that is issued by the County Commissioners.
If the person is a for profit business, the person:

subparagraph.text: shall also hold a Class A, B, C, or D retail alcoholic beverages license; and
may engage in paper gaming only on the premises of the for profit business.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, an organization may engage in paper gaming if the organization:

subparagraph.text: is listed under § 13-1403(b) of this subtitle and does not have an alcoholic beverages license; or
is a county volunteer fire department or rescue squad and has an alcoholic beverages license.

paragraph.text: An organization under paragraph (3) of this subsection may engage in paper gaming only on its premises.

subsection.text: A person may sell paper gaming devices to a paper gaming licensee if the person obtains a wholesale vendor’s license issued by the County Commissioners.
The County Commissioners shall set annual fees for a paper gaming license and a wholesale vendor’s license.

Not later than the fifteenth of each month, wholesale vendor licensees shall provide to the County Commissioners a list for the previous month of all customers to whom they sold paper gaming products and the total number of products sold to each customer.
A paper gaming licensee may not have on its premises a paper gaming device that does not display a gaming sticker issued by the county.

The County Commissioners shall ensure that each licensee who conducts paper gaming under a paper gaming license sells to the public the same serial-numbered paper gaming devices that are listed on the bill of sale from the wholesale vendor licensee.
The County Commissioners may impose the following paper gaming taxes:

paragraph.text: on licensees that are qualified organizations, 10% of gross profits minus the costs of paper gaming products; and
on licensees that are for profit businesses, 40% of gross profits minus the costs of paper gaming products.
In this subsection, “Fund” means the Special Gaming Fund.
The County Commissioners shall establish a Special Gaming Fund.
The Fund is a special continuing, nonlapsing fund.
The Fund shall be used only to benefit fire and rescue services.

subparagraph.text: The Fund consists of:

sub-subparagraph.text: revenue derived from the taxation of gross profits from tip jar sales; and
subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, money received from other sources.

subparagraph.text: Money from the General Fund of the State or the county, including any federal money, may not be transferred by budget amendment or otherwise to the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund shall be invested and reinvested in the same manner as other county funds.
Annually the County Commissioners shall:

subparagraph.text: pay from the Fund all administrative costs of carrying out this section, including the hiring of additional necessary personnel; and
allocate the remaining money in the Fund to fire and rescue services.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners may adopt rules and regulations to administer and enforce this section.
The County Commissioners may:

paragraph.text: hire or designate one or more inspectors; and
authorize each inspector to enter the premises of a licensee to ensure compliance with this section or a rule or regulation adopted under this section.

subsection.text: The County Commissioners may adopt an ordinance or resolution declaring that:

paragraph.text: a violation of this section or a rule or regulation adopted under this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a term of imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both; and
each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

subsection.text: After a hearing, if the County Commissioners or a designee of the Board finds that a paper gaming licensee, a wholesale vendor licensee, or an agent of a licensee has violated this section or a rule or regulation adopted under this section, the Board may suspend or revoke the license in addition to any fine or penalty imposed under this subsection.
A person authorized to conduct bingo under subsection (b) of this section shall obtain a bingo permit from the county agency designated by the County Commissioners to issue a bingo permit.
An organization may conduct bingo for its own benefit or to benefit charity in the county if the organization is a legal resident of the county and is:

paragraph.text: a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization;
hospital;
amateur athletic organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization; or
charitable organization;

paragraph.text: a county volunteer fire department or rescue squad; or
an auxiliary for a county volunteer fire department or rescue squad.

subsection.text: A person who is not a legal resident of the county may not conduct bingo.
To qualify for a bingo permit, a person shall meet the requirements set by the county.
Only members of an organization listed under subsection (b) of this section may conduct and operate bingo games.

section.text: The County Commissioners may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle, including age restrictions for participants in any activity involving a gaming event or bingo.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bingo”:

paragraph.text: includes instant bingo; but
does not include members-only instant bingo.

subsection.text: “50/50” means a drawing from a finite number of chances in which the proceeds from the sale of chances are split evenly between the winner and the organization conducting the game.
“Gaming event” means bingo, members-only instant bingo, a raffle, or a paddle wheel.
“Members-only instant bingo” means an instant bingo game that is limited to members and guests of an organization listed in § 13-1503(b) of this subtitle.
“Sheriff” means the Sheriff of Harford County.
This subtitle applies only in Harford County.
This subtitle does not authorize the use of a slot machine or any type of coin machine for gambling purposes.
Before an organization conducts a gaming event under this subtitle, the organization shall obtain a license from the sheriff.
The following organizations may obtain a license to conduct a gaming event:

paragraph.text: a bona fide religious group that has conducted religious services at a fixed location in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a license;
a State-chartered organization authorized by a nationally chartered veterans organization;
a tax-supported volunteer fire company; or
a nonprofit organization that intends to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose which is specifically described in the application for a license.

subsection.text: An application for a license shall contain a certification by a principal officer of the organization that states:

paragraph.text: the scheduled time and place of the gaming event and the date of any raffle drawing;
that the licensed activities will be managed and conducted solely and personally by the regular members of the organization without the assistance of gaming professionals;
that all money prizes offered will comply with the limits listed in this subtitle;

that the organization, by one of its principal officers, shall, within 15 days after the last day named in the application for conducting the licensed activities, file a report under penalties of perjury containing the information required by § 13-1509 of this subtitle; and
if the organization is a nonprofit organization that intends to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose, a specific description of the purpose.

subsection.text: The sheriff shall charge the following license fees:

paragraph.text: $5 for a bingo license;
$10 for a paddle wheel license;
$10 for a raffle license;
$10 for a 50/50 license; and
$15 for a members–only instant bingo license.

subsection.text: An activity for which a license is issued under this subtitle must be conducted and managed solely and personally by regular members of the organization:

paragraph.text: who do not regularly conduct gaming activities for any other organization; and
without the assistance of gaming professionals.
The sheriff may not issue to a single organization in 1 calendar year more than 52 bingo licenses.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, not more than one bingo license may be issued to a single organization in a single calendar week.
A license to conduct bingo is valid:

subparagraph.text: for 24 consecutive hours; or
if the license is issued for use in conjunction with and at a carnival, during carnival hours, and for the shorter of the duration of the carnival or 14 consecutive days.

subsection.text: A money prize for a bingo game may not exceed:

paragraph.text: $1,000 for a jackpot.

subsection.text: An instant bingo game may be sold and played only at the location listed on the license.
A minor may not sell or play instant bingo.
A license to operate a paddle wheel shall also operate as a license to conduct bingo, if authorized by the sheriff on request.
A members-only instant bingo license is valid for 3 months.
The sheriff may not issue to a single organization in 1 calendar year more than four licenses for members-only instant bingo.
A money prize for a members–only instant bingo game may not exceed $500.
A members-only instant bingo game may be sold and played only at the location listed on the license.

paragraph.text: The sheriff may not issue to a single organization in 1 calendar year more than 12 raffle licenses, no more than one of which may be for a raffle with a money prize exceeding $1,000.
All raffle drawings shall be conducted in 1 calendar day.
A raffle license is valid until all raffles are drawn.
A raffle license shall state the day for the drawing or drawings.

subsection.text: A money prize for a raffle may not exceed:

paragraph.text: $10,000 if the sponsoring organization has not held a raffle for a money prize exceeding $1,000 in the current calendar year; or
$1,000 if the sponsoring organization has held a raffle for a money prize exceeding $1,000 in the current calendar year.

subsection.text: An organization that intends to conduct a raffle for a money prize exceeding $1,000 shall:

paragraph.text: post a bond in the amount of the money prize; or
obtain an irrevocable letter of credit from a bank in the amount of the money prize.
The sheriff may not issue to a single organization in 1 calendar year more than 12 licenses for paddle wheels.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, not more than one paddle wheel license or bingo license may be issued to a single organization in a single calendar week.
A license to operate paddle wheels is valid:

subparagraph.text: for 24 consecutive hours; or
if the license is issued for use in conjunction with and at a carnival, during carnival hours, and for the shorter of the duration of the carnival or 14 consecutive days.

subsection.text: A money prize for a paddle wheel game may not exceed $10.
A license to operate a paddle wheel shall also operate as a license to conduct bingo, if authorized by the sheriff on request.
An organization listed in § 13–1503(b) of this subtitle may conduct a game of 50/50:

paragraph.text: without a 50/50 license, at a meeting of the organization; or
with a 50/50 license, at an event other than a meeting of the organization.

subsection.text: A money prize for a game of 50/50 may not exceed $500.
A minor may not participate in a game of 50/50.

Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, a political committee, as defined in § 1–101 of the Election Law Article, may conduct a fundraiser at which prizes of money or merchandise are awarded in a gaming event or 50/50.
A political committee may award a money or merchandise prize under this section if the prize does not exceed the amount otherwise allowed for a prize in the county.

section.text: Within 15 days after the last day of licensed activity named in the license application, one of the principal officers of the organization shall file a report under the penalties of perjury certifying:

paragraph.text: that the activities authorized by the license were conducted at the time and place stated in the application solely by the regular members of the organization without the assistance of gaming professionals, and that the members conducting the activities do not regularly conduct gaming activities for any other organization;
that money prizes were not offered, except as authorized under this subtitle; and
the amount and disposition of the cash proceeds of the activities authorized by the license.

subsection.text: An organization may not conduct a gaming event unless the organization has acquired the appropriate license.
An organization shall obey the terms of a license.
Each person who signed an application for a license shall obey the terms of the license.
A person shall file the report required under § 13-1509 of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 30 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
Each day that a gaming event is operated without a license or in violation of any of the terms of the license is a separate violation.
An organization that fails to file a report required by § 13-1509 of this subtitle is not entitled to a license under this subtitle until the later of:

paragraph.text: 1 year after the date the report is due; or
the day the report is filed properly.

subsection.text: An organization that is convicted of violating a gambling law of this State may not be issued a license under this subtitle until 1 month after the date of conviction.

section.text: The sheriff, other peace officers of the county, and municipal police in the county shall enforce this subtitle.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only in Howard County.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Howard County.
Subtitle 2 of this title does not apply to bingo regulated under § 13-1602 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Any of the following organizations may conduct bingo to benefit charity in the county or to further the purposes of the organization:

paragraph.text: a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
patriotic organization;
educational organization; or
charitable organization; or

paragraph.text: a volunteer fire company.

subsection.text: A person who is not a legal resident of the county may not conduct bingo in the county, even if the game is for the benefit of an organization listed in subsection (a) of this section.

section.text: A qualified organization under Subtitle 2 of this title may award prizes in money or merchandise using:

paragraph.text: a paddle wheel;
a wheel of fortune;
a chance book;
bingo; or
any other gaming device except:

subparagraph.text: a card game;
a dice game; or
roulette.

section.text: Notwithstanding Subtitle 2 of this title, a person may not conduct a casino night or operate any of the following gaming devices:

paragraph.text: a card game;
a dice game; or
roulette.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Kent County.
“Permit” means:

paragraph.text: a multiple gaming device permit issued under § 13-1703 of this subtitle; or
a raffle permit issued under § 13-1704 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Raffle” means a lottery in which a prize is won by a person who buys a paper chance.
This subtitle applies only in Kent County.
This subtitle does not authorize gambling using a slot machine or coin machine.

The county commissioners may issue a permit to an organization specified in subsection (c) of this section to use two or more of the following gaming devices in conducting a fundraiser at which a prize of merchandise or money may be awarded:

paragraph.text: a paddle wheel;
a wheel of fortune;
a chance book;
a card game;
a raffle; or
any other gaming device.

subsection.text: Unless conducted at an event requiring a permit under subsection (a) of this section, a raffle is not a multiple gaming device regulated under this section.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, “charity” means an organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
The county commissioners may issue a permit to use multiple gaming devices to:

subparagraph.text: a bona fide religious organization that has conducted religious services at the same location in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a permit;
a county-supported or municipally supported volunteer fire company or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the volunteer fire company or auxiliary unit;
a nationally chartered veterans’ organization or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the veterans’ organization;
for the purpose of conducting a fundraiser for the benefit of a charity located in the county, a bona fide:

sub-subparagraph.text: fraternal organization;
educational organization;
civic organization;
patriotic organization; or
charitable organization; or

subparagraph.text: a bona fide nonprofit organization that:

sub-subparagraph.text: has operated on a nonprofit basis in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a permit; and
intends to use the multiple gaming devices to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose specifically described in the permit application.

subsection.text: Before issuing a permit, the county commissioners shall determine that the organization seeking the permit:

paragraph.text: is organized in and serves the residents of the county; and
meets the conditions of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a permit is valid for one event that does not last longer than 6 hours.
The county commissioners may issue a permit for an event longer than 6 hours if the permit holder does not seek more than one permit in the same year.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may not approve a permit for gaming events to be held on premises that are licensed under a Class B or Class D alcoholic beverages license.
The county commissioners may not issue more than two permits to an organization in a single year.
The county commissioners may:

subparagraph.text: charge a fee set by resolution for each permit;
set the number of permits that may be issued each year; and
adopt regulations governing permit applications and the issuance of permits.

paragraph.text: An organization that is issued a permit shall conduct its fundraiser in a:

subparagraph.text: structure that the organization owns, leases, or occupies;
structure that any organization that would qualify for a permit owns, leases, or occupies; or
public location that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: described in the permit application; and
approved by the State’s Attorney for the county.

subparagraph.text: Unless the county commissioners grant a waiver, only a resident of the county may manage and operate a fundraiser for which a permit is issued on behalf of the permit holder.
Each permit holder shall designate an individual to be responsible for compliance with the terms and conditions of this subtitle and a permit issued under this subtitle.
A person may not be compensated for operating the gaming activity conducted under a permit.

paragraph.text: The permit holder shall use at least one-half of the funds raised using the permit for civic, charitable, or educational purposes.
Within 30 days after a fundraiser, the permit holder shall send to the county commissioners:

subparagraph.text: an accounting of all funds received or pledged;
an accounting of all expenses paid or incurred; and
a statement under oath of the application of the net profits.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may deny a permit for not more than 3 years to an organization that violates this subtitle or regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The county commissioners may issue a raffle permit to an organization that qualifies for a permit under this subtitle or under regulations that the county commissioners adopt.
The holder of a raffle permit must award the last prize in the raffle within 1 year after the date that the permit for the raffle is issued.
The county commissioners may regulate the number of raffle permits that an organization may be issued in 1 year.

section.text: To benefit charity in the county or to further the purposes of an organization qualified to conduct bingo under this section, an organization may conduct bingo if the organization is a bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
war veterans’ organization;
charitable organization; or
volunteer fire company operating in a community that does not have a paid fire department.

subsection.text: A person who violates a provision of §§ 13-1702 through 13-1704 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
Each day that a person is in violation under this section is a separate violation.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Breakout ticket” includes instant bingo, Nevada club, lucky seven, and similar games.

paragraph.text: “Qualified organization” means a bona fide nonprofit organization qualified under 26 U.S.C. § 501(c)(3), (4), (7), or (10).
“Qualified organization” includes:

subparagraph.text: a religious organization;
a volunteer fire company;
a volunteer rescue squad;
a fraternal organization;
a patriotic organization;
an educational organization; and
a charitable organization.

section.text: This subtitle applies only in Montgomery County.

paragraph.text: A qualified organization may conduct bingo in the county to benefit charity or to further the purpose of the qualified organization.
Bingo shall be conducted only by the qualified organization and not by a person who:

subparagraph.text: retains a portion of the proceeds from the bingo game; or
is compensated by the qualified organization for which the bingo is held.

paragraph.text: A person may not receive a private profit from the proceeds of bingo.
A qualified organization that conducts bingo shall:

subparagraph.text: keep accurate records of all transactions that occur on behalf of the bingo game;
keep the records for 2 years after the bingo game; and
on request, make the records available for examination by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the State's Attorney for the county;
the county sheriff;
the county Department of Health and Human Services;
the county attorney;
the Department of State Police; or
a designated officer or agent of any of those units.

paragraph.text: A person conducting bingo shall be a resident of the county and a member of the qualified organization.
Alcoholic beverages may not be sold or consumed in the room in which bingo is conducted, either during a game or an intermission between games.
Money prizes not exceeding $1,000 in each game may be awarded in bingo.
The qualified organization may sell breakout tickets in the room in which bingo is conducted, either during a game or an intermission between games.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, a person may conduct bingo at the annual Montgomery County Fair for the benefit of the Montgomery County Agricultural Center, Inc.
A person who conducts bingo under this subsection may award only noncash prizes.

section.text: A qualified organization that conducts bingo in the county shall be licensed by the county under this subtitle.
A qualified organization that conducts bingo in the county shall be located in the county.

subsection.text: A qualified organization that intends to conduct bingo shall submit a bingo license application on a form that the county provides.
A qualified organization shall disclose the following information on the license application:

paragraph.text: the name of the qualified organization, and the names and addresses of its officers and directors;
a complete statement of the purposes and objectives of the qualified organization and the purposes for which the qualified organization will use the proceeds from the bingo;
a statement under oath by the president and treasurer, or the chief executive and fiscal officer, of the qualified organization that:

subparagraph.text: an agreement does not exist to divert any of the proceeds of the bingo to another person; and
another person will not receive any of the proceeds of the bingo except to further the purpose of the qualified organization; and

paragraph.text: any additional information that the county requires.

section.text: The county may issue an annual bingo license authorizing the holder to conduct bingo at a specified fixed location:

paragraph.text: at any time during the year for which the license is issued; but
not to exceed twice in any 1 week.

subsection.text: The county may issue:

paragraph.text: one temporary 10-day bingo license to each applicant each calendar year at a fee determined by the county; or

a 1-day bingo license at a fee determined by the county, not to exceed three 1-day licenses to each applicant each calendar year, authorizing the holder to conduct bingo at a specified fixed location for 1 day.

subsection.text: A temporary 10-day bingo license authorizes the holder to conduct bingo at a specified fixed location for a maximum of 10 days in any 1 year.
The county shall:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations for the conduct of bingo;
establish license fees, based on the administrative cost of regulating bingo and issuing each class of license; and
establish the hours of operation for bingo.

subsection.text: After a public hearing, the county may revoke a bingo license for failure of the holder to comply with this subtitle or regulations adopted under this subtitle.
A qualified organization may conduct a raffle in the county to benefit charity or to further the purpose of the qualified organization.
A raffle shall be conducted by a qualified organization and not by a person who:

paragraph.text: retains a portion of the proceeds from the raffle; or
is compensated by the qualified organization for which the raffle is held.

subsection.text: A person may not receive a private profit from the proceeds of a raffle.
A qualified organization that conducts a raffle shall:

paragraph.text: keep accurate records of all transactions that occur on behalf of the raffle;
keep the records for 2 years after the raffle; and
on request, make the records available for examination by:

subparagraph.text: the State’s Attorney for the county;
the county sheriff;
the county Department of Health and Human Services;
the county attorney;
the Department of State Police; or
a designated officer or agent of any of those units.

subsection.text: A person operating a raffle shall be a resident of the county and a member of the qualified organization.
Prizes of money or merchandise may be awarded in a raffle conducted under this subtitle.
For a raffle of real property, the requirements of this section are in addition to the requirements of § 12-106(a) of this article.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a qualified organization may not conduct more than 12 raffles each year.
There is no limit to the number of 50/50 raffles that a qualified organization may conduct if the prize for each 50/50 raffle does not exceed $300.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a qualified organization that intends to conduct a raffle in the county shall obtain a permit from the county.
A permit is not required to conduct a 50/50 raffle.

section.text: A qualified organization that conducts a raffle in the county shall be located in the county.

subsection.text: A qualified organization shall apply for a raffle permit on a form that the county provides.
A qualified organization shall disclose the following information on the permit application:

paragraph.text: the name of the qualified organization, and the names and addresses of its officers and directors;
a complete statement of the purposes and objectives of the qualified organization, and the purposes for which the qualified organization will use the proceeds from the raffle;
a statement under oath by the president and treasurer, or the chief executive and fiscal officer, of the qualified organization that:

subparagraph.text: an agreement does not exist to divert any of the proceeds of the raffle to another; and
another person will not receive any of the proceeds of the raffle except to further the purpose of the qualified organization;

paragraph.text: in the case of a raffle of real property, under § 12-106(a) of this article, a copy of the disclosure statement filed with the Secretary of State; and
any additional information that the county requires.

section.text: The county:

paragraph.text: may adopt regulations necessary for the conduct of a raffle; and
after a public hearing, may revoke the permit of a holder for failure to comply with this subtitle or regulations adopted under this subtitle.

section.text: A person who violates this subtitle or a regulation adopted by the county under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine of $1,000 or both.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Benefit performance” includes an outdoor carnival, indoor carnival, fair, picnic, dance, card party, bingo party, bazaar, concert, contest, exhibition, lecture, barbecue, or dinner.

paragraph.text: “Qualified organization” means an organization of a group of citizens of the county or a company, association, or corporation that is organized in good faith in the county to promote the purposes of a volunteer fire department or of a charitable, benevolent, patriotic, fraternal, educational, religious, or civic object.
“Qualified organization” does not include a group organized for the private profit or gain of any member of the group, company, association, or corporation.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only in Prince George’s County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Prince George’s County.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a qualified organization may conduct a benefit performance to which the public is invited or admitted with or without charge.
The net proceeds of the benefit performance:

paragraph.text: shall benefit the qualified organization;
shall be used for the purposes of the qualified organization; and
may not benefit the private gain of a member of the qualified organization.

subsection.text: A benefit performance shall be personally managed and conducted only by members of the qualified organization that sponsors the benefit performance.

paragraph.text: At a benefit performance, a qualified organization may:

subparagraph.text: conduct games of skill; or
dispose of merchandise and other things of value by auction, voting, or using a mechanical device such as a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, bingo, or similar device.

paragraph.text: The activities allowed under this subsection may be conducted with or without an entrance or participation fee.

section.text: A qualified organization shall obtain a written permit from the governing body of the county or its designee before conducting a benefit performance.
At a benefit performance, a qualified organization may award:

paragraph.text: a merchandise prize; or
a money prize of not more than $1,000 per prize.

section.text: A person who conducts or attempts to conduct a benefit performance in violation of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, a qualified organization may conduct a raffle.

paragraph.text: The proceeds of a raffle:

subparagraph.text: shall benefit the qualified organization; and
shall be used for the purposes of the qualified organization.

paragraph.text: Except for a bona fide raffle winner, an individual or group may not:

subparagraph.text: benefit financially from the holding of a raffle; or
receive or be paid any proceeds from a raffle for personal use or benefit.

section.text: A raffle shall be personally conducted and managed only by regular members of the qualified organization.

subsection.text: A qualified organization shall obtain a written permit from the Department of Environmental Resources before conducting a raffle if the total cash value of the prize exceeds $200.

paragraph.text: Before issuing a permit, the Department of Environmental Resources shall ascertain the character of the qualified organization applying for a permit under this section to determine if the application complies with this subtitle.
A permit issued to a qualified organization to conduct a raffle may not be transferred.

subsection.text: The permit fee for each raffle is $15.

section.text: A qualified organization conducting a raffle may award prizes in money not exceeding a total of $5,000 and in merchandise in any amount or the merchandise cash equivalent.

subsection.text: In this section:

paragraph.text: “casino night” means a benefit performance at which:

subparagraph.text: a card game, wheel of chance, or roulette is played; and
money winnings or tokens redeemable in money are awarded as prizes; but

paragraph.text: “casino night” does not include a benefit performance at which the only form of gaming is a wheel of fortune, big wheel, or other wheel of chance.
This subtitle and Subtitle 2 of this title do not authorize casino nights in the county.
A person may not conduct a casino night in the county.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section or a county ordinance enacted under this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 3 years or a fine not exceeding $5,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Queen Anne’s County.
“Permit” means:

paragraph.text: a multiple gaming device permit issued under § 13-2003 of this subtitle; or
a raffle permit issued under § 13-2004 of this subtitle.
“Raffle” means a lottery in which a prize is won by a person who buys a paper chance.
A “raffle” is not a multiple gaming device regulated under § 13-2003 of this subtitle unless run in conjunction with an event that requires a multiple gaming device permit.

subsection.text: This subtitle applies only in Queen Anne’s County.
This subtitle does not authorize gambling using a slot machine or coin machine.

An organization listed in subsection (b) of this section shall obtain a permit from the county commissioners before the organization may use two or more of the following gaming devices in conducting a fundraiser at which prizes of merchandise or money may be awarded:

paragraph.text: a paddle wheel;
a wheel of fortune;
a chance book;
a card game;
a raffle; or
any other gaming device.
In this subsection, “charity” means an organization, institution, association, society, or corporation that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this subtitle, the county commissioners may issue a permit to use multiple gaming devices to an organization if the organization is:

subparagraph.text: a bona fide religious organization that has conducted religious services at the same location in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a permit;

a county-supported or municipally supported volunteer fire company or an auxiliary unit of the volunteer fire company whose members are directly associated with the volunteer fire company or auxiliary unit;
a nationally chartered veterans’ organization or an auxiliary unit of the veterans’ organization whose members are directly associated with the veterans’ organization;
if the organization intends to use two or more gaming devices to conduct a fundraiser for the benefit of a charity located in the county, an organization that is a bona fide:

sub-subparagraph.text: fraternal organization;
educational organization;
civic organization;
patriotic organization; or
charitable organization; or

subparagraph.text: a bona fide nonprofit organization that:

sub-subparagraph.text: has operated on a nonprofit basis in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a permit; and
intends to use the multiple gaming devices to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose specifically described in the permit application.

subsection.text: Before issuing a permit, the county commissioners shall determine that the organization seeking the permit:

paragraph.text: is organized in and serves the residents of the county; and
meets the conditions of this section.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a permit is valid for one event that does not last longer than 6 hours.
The county commissioners may issue a permit for an event longer than 6 hours if the permit holder does not seek more than one permit in the same year.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may not approve a permit for gaming events to be held on premises that are licensed under a Class B or Class D alcoholic beverages license.
The county commissioners may not issue more than two permits to an organization in a single year.
The county commissioners may:

subparagraph.text: charge a fee set by resolution for each permit;
set the number of permits that may be issued each year; and
adopt regulations governing permit applications and the issuance of permits.

paragraph.text: An organization that is issued a permit shall conduct its fundraiser in:

subparagraph.text: a structure that the organization owns, leases, or occupies;
a structure that any organization that would qualify for a permit owns, leases, or occupies; or
a public location that is:

sub-subparagraph.text: described in the permit application; and
approved by the State’s Attorney for the county.

subparagraph.text: Unless the county commissioners grant a waiver, a fundraiser for which a permit is issued shall be managed and operated only by individuals who reside in the county and on behalf of the permit holder.
Each permit holder shall designate an individual to be responsible for compliance with the terms and conditions of this subtitle and a permit issued under this subtitle.
A person may not be compensated for operating the gaming activity conducted under a permit.

paragraph.text: The permit holder shall use at least one-half of the funds raised using the permit for civic, charitable, or educational purposes.
Within 30 days after a fundraiser, the permit holder shall send to the county commissioners:

subparagraph.text: an accounting of all funds received or pledged;
an accounting of all expenses paid or incurred; and
a statement under oath of the application of the net profits.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may deny a permit for not more than 3 years to an organization that violates this subtitle or regulations adopted under this subtitle.
The county commissioners may issue a raffle permit to an organization that qualifies for a permit under § 13-2003 of this subtitle or under regulations that the county commissioners adopt.
The holder of a raffle permit must award the last prize in the raffle within 1 year after the date that the permit for the raffle is issued.
The county commissioners may regulate the number of raffle permits that an organization may be issued in 1 year.

section.text: To benefit charity in the county or to further its purposes, an entity may conduct bingo if the entity is a bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
charitable organization; or
volunteer fire company operating in a community that does not have a paid fire department.

subsection.text: A person who violates a provision of § 13-2002, § 13-2003, or § 13-2004 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
Each day that a person violates this section is a separate violation.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of St. Mary’s County.

paragraph.text: “Gaming device” includes a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, chance book, bingo, Nevada card, and a stamp machine.
“Gaming device” does not include a slot machine, as defined in § 12-301 of this article.

subsection.text: “Gaming event” means a carnival, bazaar, or raffle.
“Qualified organization” means:

paragraph.text: a volunteer fire company; or
a bona fide:

subparagraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
civic organization;
war veterans’ organization; or
charitable organization.

subsection.text: “Sheriff” means the Sheriff of St. Mary’s County.
This subtitle applies only in St. Mary’s County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in St. Mary’s County.

section.text: A qualified organization must have a bingo license whenever the qualified organization conducts bingo.
To be eligible for a bingo license, an organization must be:

paragraph.text: a bona fide religious group that has conducted religious services at a fixed location in the county for at least 3 years before the application date;

a volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue squad, regardless of whether the company or squad is supported by tax revenues, or an auxiliary unit whose members are associated directly with the company or squad;
a nationally chartered veterans’ organization, or an auxiliary unit whose members are associated directly with the organization; or
a nonprofit organization that:

subparagraph.text: has operated in the county for at least 3 years before the application date; and
intends to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose specifically described in the application.

subsection.text: An organization shall submit an application for a bingo license to the sheriff.
A principal officer of the organization shall certify in the application for a bingo license:

paragraph.text: the name and address of the organization;
the name and address of the officer seeking the license for the organization;
that the officer is authorized by the organization to file the application;
the time and place of bingo;

that, within 15 days after the last day named in the application for the license to conduct bingo, a principal officer of the organization will file under penalties of perjury the report required by § 13-2109 of this subtitle;
that bingo will be conducted solely and personally by the regular members of the organization, without the assistance of gaming professionals; and
that no compensation or reward will be paid to a person for conducting or assisting in conducting bingo.

subsection.text: By resolution, the county commissioners may establish a bingo license fee schedule based on criteria that the county commissioners consider appropriate.
The sheriff shall charge for each license the annual license fee that the county commissioners set by resolution.
A resolution adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall specify the fund in which the license fees are to be deposited.

section.text: The sheriff shall issue a numbered license to an organization that meets the requirements of §§ 13-2103 through 13-2110 of this subtitle to conduct bingo and award prizes.
A license issued under this subtitle is valid for 1 year.
Within 15 days after the last day authorized for bingo in the license, a principal officer of the organization shall file a report under penalties of perjury that certifies:

paragraph.text: that the regular members of the organization personally conducted bingo at the time and place stated in the application without the assistance of gaming professionals;
the disposition of the cash proceeds of the bingo; and
that the organization did not pay a premises rental fee to:

subparagraph.text: itself;
its trustees;
a committee of the organization; or
any organization whose members are the same, or substantially the same, as the licensed organization.

section.text: An organization is disqualified from obtaining a license under this subtitle for 1 year if the organization fails to:

paragraph.text: file the report required under § 13-2109 of this subtitle; or
comply with §§ 13-2103 through 13-2110 of this subtitle.

section.text: A qualified organization may hold a gaming event and may operate a gaming device if an individual or group of individuals does not:

paragraph.text: benefit financially from the operation of the gaming device; or
receive from the operation of the gaming device any proceeds for personal use or benefit.

section.text: Members of the qualified organization shall personally manage the operation of the gaming device.
If a qualified organization uses a gaming device on a daily basis:

paragraph.text: the qualified organization may not operate more than five gaming devices; and
the premises in which the qualified organization operates the gaming device may not contain more than five gaming devices.

subsection.text: All proceeds from a gaming device shall be used solely for the legitimate charitable, benevolent, or tax-exempt purposes of the qualified organization.
Proceeds from the operation of a gaming device may not be used to benefit personally any member of the qualified organization.
A qualified organization shall keep accurate records of proceeds and expenditures involving gaming devices.

On request, a qualified organization shall allow the State’s Attorney for the county, a State Police officer, and the sheriff or deputy sheriff to examine the records required under subsection (a) of this section.
This subtitle applies only in Somerset County.
Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Somerset County.

section.text: To benefit charity in the county or to further the purposes of an organization qualified to conduct bingo under this section, an organization may conduct bingo if the organization is a bona fide:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
fraternal organization;
war veterans’ organization;
charitable organization; or
volunteer fire company operating in a community that does not have a paid fire department.

section.text: Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Talbot County.
In this subtitle, “county commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Washington County.
This subtitle applies only in Washington County.
Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, Subtitle 2 of this title applies in Washington County.

subsection.text: A volunteer rescue company shall be treated as a volunteer fire company for purposes of Subtitle 2 of this title.

A person may not operate a chance book, paddle wheel, tip jar, wheel of fortune, or other gaming device, other than a bingo game, on premises that are owned by, leased to, or used as a place of business by a person that conducts a bingo game for purposes of making a profit.

paragraph.text: Subtitle 2 of this title does not apply to the operation of tip jars.
Tip jars are regulated under Part III of this subtitle.

section.text: Bingo may be conducted in accordance with Part II of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Before a person may conduct bingo, the person shall obtain a bingo permit from the county commissioners.

paragraph.text: Before issuing a bingo permit, the county commissioners shall ascertain:

subparagraph.text: the purpose of the bingo game; and
the intended use of receipts from bingo.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may not issue a new bingo permit for bingo that is to be conducted for profit.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a nonprofit organization seeking a bingo permit.
The county commissioners may charge an annual fee not exceeding $5,000 for a bingo permit.

section.text: A person may not give or offer in a single bingo game:

paragraph.text: a money prize exceeding $1,000;
a merchandise prize exceeding a value of $1,000; or
a prize of money and merchandise with a combined value exceeding $1,000.

subsection.text: A person may not conduct bingo in violation of Part II of this subtitle.
A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
Each day that a violation occurs is a separate violation.
In Part III of this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Agency” means the county agency that the county commissioners designate to administer Part III of this subtitle.
“Fund” means the Washington County Gaming Fund.
“Gaming commission” means the Washington County Gaming Commission.
“Tip jar” means:

paragraph.text: a gaming device from which for consideration a number, series of numbers, or other symbol is obtained by selection of a sealed piece of paper that may entitle the purchaser to a payoff in money or otherwise, either on receipt or as the result of a subsequent announcement of a winning number, series of numbers, or other symbol; or
any other device commonly recognized as a tip jar.

subsection.text: “Tip jar license” means a license that the agency issues to operate a tip jar.

“Tip jar packet” means a package of numbers, series of numbers, or symbols on folded or sealed pieces of paper that is designed to be sold through a tip jar and that is sufficient for a single tip jar game.
“Wholesaler’s license” means a license that the agency issues to sell or wholesale tip jar packets for profit.

section.text: There is a Washington County Gaming Commission.

paragraph.text: The gaming commission consists of seven members.
Of the seven members of the gaming commission:

subparagraph.text: three shall be appointed by the county commissioners;
one shall be appointed by the State Senators whose districts are in or include part of the county;
one shall be appointed by the chairperson of the county delegation to the House of Delegates, with the concurrence of that delegation;
one shall be from the Washington County Clubs Association, appointed by the county Senate and House delegations; and
one shall be a representative of the alcoholic beverages, restaurant, and tavern industries in the county, appointed by the county Senate and House delegations.

subsection.text: Each member of the gaming commission shall be a resident of the county.

paragraph.text: A member appointed to the gaming commission under subsection (a)(2)(i), (ii), or (iii) of this section may not:

subparagraph.text: hold a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license or be employed by a person who holds a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license; or
hold an ownership interest in or receive a direct benefit from a person who holds a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license.

paragraph.text: If a member of the gaming commission serves on the board of directors or as an officer of an organization and that organization applies for funds from the gaming commission, the member shall cease immediately to serve on the gaming commission.

The term of a member of the gaming commission is 2 years and begins on March 1 or October 1, according to the staggered schedule required by the terms provided for members of the gaming commission on October 1, 2002.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

subsection.text: A member who completes two full terms on the gaming commission may not be reappointed within the 5 years after the end of the second term.
Each year the gaming commission shall elect a chairperson from among its members.
The manner of election of a chairperson shall be as the gaming commission determines.
A member of the gaming commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses, in accordance with a policy of the county commissioners.

subsection.text: The county commissioners shall assign appropriate professional staff to the gaming commission for the gaming commission’s meetings.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall adopt regulations to carry out Part III of this subtitle.
The agency may recommend to the county commissioners regulations or guidelines concerning the administration of Part III of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The county commissioners shall make available for public inspection:

paragraph.text: audit reports completed under § 13-2432(a) of this subtitle; and
in accordance with regulations of the county commissioners, tip jar reports submitted under § 13-2424 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: By regulation, the county commissioners may require:

paragraph.text: an applicant for a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license or an individual involved in the operation of a tip jar to be fingerprinted for purposes of a criminal history records check; and
the agency to obtain a criminal history records check in accordance with subsection (d) of this section.

If the county commissioners direct the agency to obtain criminal history records checks, the agency shall apply to the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services for a State criminal history records check for each:

subparagraph.text: applicant for a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license; and
individual involved in the operation of a tip jar.

paragraph.text: As part of the application for a criminal history records check, the agency shall submit to the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository:

subparagraph.text: a complete set of the applicant’s or individual’s legible fingerprints on forms approved by the director of the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository; and
the fee authorized under § 10-221(b)(7) of the Criminal Procedure Article.

paragraph.text: The Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository shall provide the requested information in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the Criminal Procedure Article.

subsection.text: A person shall be licensed by the agency before operating a tip jar.
To be eligible for a license to operate a tip jar, an applicant shall be a:

paragraph.text: religious organization;
civic organization;
fraternal organization;
veterans’ organization;
bona fide charitable organization;
sportsmen’s association that is tax exempt under § 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code and that is approved by the county commissioners;
holder of a Class A beer, wine and liquor license;
restaurant with an alcoholic beverages license;
tavern with an alcoholic beverages license;
volunteer fire company; or
volunteer rescue company.
A person may not receive a tip jar license if the person:

subparagraph.text: owes taxes to the State, the county, or a municipal corporation in the county;
unless authorized under paragraph (2) of this subsection, holds a wholesaler’s license; or
has been convicted of a:

sub-subparagraph.text: felony; or
misdemeanor involving a violation of a gambling or gaming law of the State.

paragraph.text: A volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue company may hold both a tip jar license and wholesaler’s license.
An applicant for a tip jar license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the agency an application on the form that the agency provides; and
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, pay an annual fee of $250 to the county.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners may waive or reduce the annual fee for an organization that qualifies for a license under § 13-2420(b)(1) through (6), (10), or (11) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The county shall credit license fees collected under subsection (a)(1)(ii) of this section to the general fund of the county.

section.text: The agency may issue a tip jar license to each applicant that meets the requirements of Part III of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Unless otherwise authorized by the county commissioners, a tip jar licensee may operate a tip jar game only:

paragraph.text: during normal business hours; and
on the tip jar licensee’s premises.

subsection.text: A tip jar licensee may award prizes in money or merchandise for a tip jar game.
The agency periodically shall send an agent to inspect the premises of each tip jar licensee to ensure compliance with Part III of this subtitle.
At least three times a year, a tip jar licensee shall submit to the county commissioners a report concerning the tip jars the person operates.
Each report shall:

paragraph.text: identify gaming stickers used;
indicate the number of tip jars in operation;
indicate the number of tip jar packets purchased; and
include any additional information that the county commissioners require.
This subsection only applies to a person who qualifies for a tip jar license under § 13-2420(b)(7), (8), or (9) of this subtitle.

In accordance with regulations of the county commissioners, a person subject to this subsection shall include in each report an accounting of receipts and disbursements made in connection with tip jars for the reporting period.

subsection.text: Each report shall include a written statement, signed by the individual making the report, in which the individual affirms under the penalties of Part III of this subtitle and under the penalty of perjury that the contents of the report are true to the best of the individual’s knowledge, information, and belief.

paragraph.text: This subsection only applies to an organization that qualifies for a tip jar license under § 13-2420(b)(1) through (6) of this subtitle.
Each report for an organization that is subject to this subsection:

subparagraph.text: shall be filed by an officer of the organization; and
in accordance with regulations of the county commissioners, shall include for the reporting period an accounting of:

sub-subparagraph.text: all receipts in connection with the operation of a tip jar; and
the disbursements made in compliance with § 13-2435(e) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: In filing a report under this subsection, the officer of the organization may not:

subparagraph.text: fraudulently use a false or fictitious name;
knowingly conceal a material fact;
knowingly make a false statement; or
otherwise commit fraud.

paragraph.text: A person who violates paragraph (3) of this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

subsection.text: A tip jar license expires on the first July 1 after its effective date.
A tip jar license is not transferable.

By regulation, the county commissioners may establish a temporary tip jar license for a nonprofit organization that desires to raise money solely for an athletic, charitable, or educational purpose that:

paragraph.text: meets the requirements for a charitable contribution under § 170(c) of the Internal Revenue Code; and
does not benefit a:

subparagraph.text: law enforcement agency;
law enforcement fraternal organization;
political club, political committee, or political party; or
unit of the State government or of a political subdivision of the State other than:

sub-subparagraph.text: an ambulance, fire fighting, or rescue squad; or
a primary or secondary school or an institution of higher education.

subsection.text: If the county commissioners establish a temporary tip jar license, by regulation, the county commissioners shall:

paragraph.text: set the fee for a temporary tip jar license;
set the term of a temporary tip jar license;
prescribe which provisions of Part III of this subtitle apply to the issuance of a temporary tip jar license and the operation of a tip jar under a temporary tip jar license; and
establish any additional requirements that the county commissioners consider appropriate concerning operation of a tip jar under a temporary tip jar license.

subsection.text: An organization that receives a temporary tip jar license is subject to audit by the gaming commission.
An individual involved in the operation of a tip jar under a temporary tip jar license may not personally benefit financially from the operation of the tip jar.
If an organization that has operated a tip jar under a temporary tip jar license disbands, the organization shall transfer any remaining proceeds from the operation of a tip jar to the fund.
A person shall be licensed by the agency as a wholesaler before the person may sell a tip jar packet for profit.

paragraph.text: A person is eligible for a license under this section to sell or wholesale for profit a tip jar packet if the person:

subparagraph.text: is of good moral character;

except for a volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue company, has had an established place of business in the county for at least 3 years, as evidenced by the filing of personal property tax returns;
in the case of a volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue company, has been established in the county for at least 1 year;
does not owe taxes to the State, the county, or a municipal corporation in the county;
unless authorized under paragraph (2) of this subsection, does not hold a tip jar license;
has not been convicted of a:

sub-subparagraph.text: felony; or
misdemeanor involving a violation of a gambling or gaming law of the State;

subparagraph.text: except for a volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue company, does not hold a tip jar license or own or have in any way an interest in an entity that holds a tip jar license;

except for a volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue company, is not an immediate family member of a person who holds a tip jar license or owns or has in any way an interest in an entity that holds a tip jar license; and
is not a corporation, limited liability company, or unincorporated association in which at least one stockholder or member is a holder of a tip jar license.

paragraph.text: A volunteer fire company or volunteer rescue company may hold both a tip jar license and a wholesaler’s license.
An applicant for a wholesaler’s license shall:

subparagraph.text: submit to the agency an application on the form that the agency provides; and
subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, pay to the agency an annual fee of $500.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall waive the annual fee for a volunteer fire company or a volunteer rescue company.

subsection.text: The agency shall credit license fees collected under subsection (a)(1)(ii) of this section to the general fund of the county.

section.text: The agency may issue a wholesaler’s license to each applicant that meets the requirements of Part III of this subtitle.

subsection.text: A holder of a wholesaler’s license may not sell a tip jar packet to a person who does not have a tip jar license.
Before selling a tip jar packet, a holder of a wholesaler’s license shall:

paragraph.text: obtain a gaming sticker from the agency; and
