affix the gaming sticker to the tip jar packet in the manner the county commissioners require.

subsection.text: A wholesaler’s license expires on the first July 1 after its effective date.
A wholesaler’s license is not transferable.
The county commissioners may audit records relating to tip jars of a holder of a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license.

In accordance with regulations of the county commissioners, a holder of a tip jar license or a wholesaler’s license shall make available to an auditor designated by the county commissioners the records that are required for an audit.
A holder of a tip jar license or a wholesaler’s license shall retain for at least 5 years the records that are required by the county commissioners by regulation.
Subject to the hearing provisions of § 13-2434 of this subtitle, the agency may:

paragraph.text: deny a tip jar license or a wholesaler’s license to an applicant; or
in accordance with § 13-2437 of this subtitle, discipline a holder of a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license.

subsection.text: The agency shall deny a license to an applicant whose tip jar license or wholesaler’s license has been revoked.

If the license of a holder of a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license is revoked for two separate civil violations under § 13-2437 of this subtitle or a criminal violation under § 13-2424(e) or § 13-2438(a) of this subtitle, the agency may deny a tip jar license or wholesaler’s license to:

paragraph.text: a corporate or limited liability entity applicant if 50% or more of the capital stock is owned by an individual, or an immediate family member of an individual, whose license was revoked; or
a partnership applicant if the partnership includes as a partner an individual whose license was revoked.

subsection.text: Before the agency takes action under § 13-2433(a) of this subtitle, it shall give the person against whom the action is contemplated the opportunity for a hearing.
If a hearing is requested, the county commissioners shall:

paragraph.text: give notice and hold the hearing in accordance with Title 10, Subtitle 2 of the State Government Article; or
delegate to the Office of Administrative Hearings the authority to hold the hearing.

subsection.text: If the county commissioners hold the hearing, the county commissioners may administer oaths in connection with the hearing.

paragraph.text: If the Office of Administrative Hearings holds the hearing:

subparagraph.text: the administrative law judge shall state on the record the conclusions of law and findings of fact; and

subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the determination of the administrative law judge is a final decision for purposes of judicial review in the same manner as a final decision in a contested case under § 10-222 of the State Government Article.

paragraph.text: In an appeal of a decision of the administrative law judge:

subparagraph.text: if the civil penalty is less than $5,000, judicial review of disputed issues of fact shall be confined to the record; or
if the civil penalty is $5,000 or more, judicial review shall be de novo.

subsection.text: After notice, if the person against whom the action is contemplated:

paragraph.text: fails or refuses to appear, nevertheless the county commissioners may hear and determine the matter; or
does not request a hearing, the county commissioners may impose a civil penalty without a hearing.

subsection.text: In this section, “gross profits” means the total proceeds from the operation of a tip jar less the amount of money winnings or value of prizes distributed.
There is a Washington County Gaming Fund.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall establish:

subparagraph.text: the method and time of deposits to the fund; and
other procedures necessary to carry out subsections (d), (e), and (f) of this section.

paragraph.text: In accordance with a written agreement between the county commissioners and the gaming commission, the gaming commission may use money from the fund to reimburse the county commissioners for the costs to the county for administering Part III of this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: The county commissioners may require the Washington County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association to submit financial reports of the Association.
The county commissioners may adopt regulations specifying the time frames for submission of the reports, but the regulations shall be limited in scope to the timing of submission of the reports only.

The financial reports of the Washington County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association may include an annual budget as approved under paragraph (4) of this subsection, budget reports, and related documentation that shows how money has been spent by the Washington County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association during the previous fiscal year.

If the financial reports are not submitted within the time required under the regulations, the county commissioners may withhold funds that would otherwise be distributed under subsection (f)(1) of this section until the reports are submitted.
Each year the Washington County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association shall submit its budget to the county commissioners.
The county commissioners shall accept or reject the budget by a majority vote.
The acceptance or rejection of the budget may not be delegated to any designee.

The county commissioners may withhold funds that would otherwise be distributed under subsection (f)(1) of this section until the budget of the Washington County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association is accepted by the county commissioners.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to a person who holds a tip jar license under § 13–2420(b)(7), (8), or (9) of this subtitle.

Subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, a person subject to this subsection shall deposit with a financial institution designated by the gaming commission, to the credit of the fund, the gross profits from each tip jar that the person operates.
To offset the costs of operating a tip jar, a person with a tip jar license may retain the lesser of $45 or 50% of the gross profits from each tip jar game.
This subsection applies only to a person who holds a tip jar license under § 13–2420(b)(1) through (6) of this subtitle.

A person subject to this subsection shall deposit with a financial institution designated by the gaming commission, to the credit of the fund, 15% of the gross profits earned through the operation of tip jars during the 12–month period ending June 30.
If a person fails to contribute the full amount required under paragraph (2) of this subsection, the person shall deposit the balance required during the next year.

subsection.text: After the reimbursement under subsection (c)(2) of this section, each year the gaming commission shall distribute:

paragraph.text: 50% of the money deposited in the fund to the Washington County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association; and
subject to any restriction that the county commissioners adopt by regulation, 50% of the money deposited in the fund to bona fide charitable organizations in the county.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may not require that funds distributed under (f)(1) of this section be used for fire and rescue services for which funds previously have been appropriated in the county operating budget.
Unless licensed to operate a tip jar by the agency, a person may not offer to another a chance from a tip jar or otherwise operate a tip jar.
A holder of a tip jar license may not:

paragraph.text: allow a minor to play a tip jar; or
operate a tip jar on property owned by the Board of Education of Washington County.

subsection.text: Unless licensed as a wholesaler to sell tip jar packets by the agency, a person may not sell or wholesale a tip jar packet for profit.
If a person violates Part III of this subtitle, the person is subject to:

paragraph.text: for a first violation, suspension of the person’s tip jar license or wholesaler’s license and a civil penalty not exceeding $1,500; or
for each subsequent violation, revocation of the person’s tip jar license or wholesaler’s license and a civil penalty not exceeding $5,000.

subsection.text: In addition to the penalties under subsection (a)(2) of this section, if the person has a liquor license, the agency may recommend to the Board of License Commissioners for Washington County that the Board suspend the person’s liquor license for not less than 15 days for a subsequent violation.
Civil penalties collected under subsection (a) of this section shall be credited to the general fund of the county.

paragraph.text: A person who violates § 13-2436 of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding:

subparagraph.text: for a first violation, $5,000; or
for each subsequent violation, $10,000.

paragraph.text: Each sale or offer of a chance from a tip jar is a separate violation.

subsection.text: If a person convicted under this section has a liquor license, the agency shall recommend to the Board of License Commissioners for Washington County that the Board suspend the person’s liquor license for not less than 15 days.

section.text: On or before February 1 of each year, the gaming commission shall submit a report to the Comptroller that includes:

paragraph.text: the total amount of revenue received by the gaming commission for the previous calendar year as a result of the operation of tip jars in Washington County;
a detailed listing of the total distributions made by the gaming commission during the previous calendar year with regard to revenue received from the operation of tip jars in Washington County; and
any additional information that the Comptroller may require.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Committee” means the Gaming Advisory Committee established under § 13-2505 of this subtitle.
“Sheriff” means the Sheriff of Wicomico County.
This subtitle applies only in Wicomico County.
This subtitle does not authorize gambling using a slot machine or a coin machine.
The sheriff may issue a license to an organization listed in subsection (b) of this section to conduct a game that uses any of the following devices to award prizes of merchandise or money:

paragraph.text: a paddle wheel;
a wheel of fortune;
a chance book;
bingo;
a raffle; or
any other gaming device.

subsection.text: To qualify for a license under this subtitle, an organization shall be:

paragraph.text: a bona fide religious organization that has conducted religious services at a fixed location in the county for at least 5 years before the organization applies for a license;
a tax–supported volunteer fire company or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the fire company;
an organization that has been located in the county for at least 5 years before it applies for a license and is:

subparagraph.text: a nationally chartered veterans’ organization or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the veterans’ organization;
a nonprofit organization that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code;
a nonprofit fraternal organization that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(10) of the Internal Revenue Code; or
a nonprofit organization that:

sub-subparagraph.text: intends to use the gaming license to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose that meets the conditions of subsection (c) of this section; and
states the charitable, athletic, or educational purpose in the application to the sheriff.

subsection.text: For the purposes of subsection (b)(3)(iv) of this section, a purpose is considered a charitable, athletic, or educational purpose if the purpose:

paragraph.text: meets the requirements for a charitable contribution under § 170(c) of the Internal Revenue Code; and
does not benefit a:

subparagraph.text: law enforcement unit;
fraternal organization for a law enforcement unit;
political club;
political committee;
political party; or
unit of State government or a political subdivision of the State other than:

sub-subparagraph.text: an ambulance company;
a fire fighting company;
a rescue company;
a primary school;
a secondary school; or
an institution of higher education.

paragraph.text: An applicant for a license shall submit an application to the sheriff.
The application shall contain:

subparagraph.text: a copy of the tax–exempt verification of the organization;
a copy of the applicant’s charter, if applicable; and
a certification by a principal officer of the applicant stating:

sub-subparagraph.text: the dates for which the license is sought;
the place at which the game will be conducted;
the type of game for which the license is sought;
that only the regular members of the applicant will conduct the games and operate the gaming device for which the license is sought;
that the applicant will not use the assistance of gaming professionals in conducting games or operating gaming devices;
that persons conducting the games and operating the gaming devices or assisting in conducting the games and operating the gaming devices will not receive compensation or reward; and
that all proceeds obtained under the license will be used to further the purposes of the organization.

paragraph.text: The sheriff shall retain the copies of the applicant’s verification of tax exemption and charter.
The sheriff may issue a license:

subparagraph.text: for one or more specific dates; or
for a period not exceeding 1 year.

paragraph.text: The licensing year shall run from July 1 through the following June 30.
The license shall state:

subparagraph.text: the dates that the game will be conducted;
the place that the game will be conducted; and
the type of game authorized.

paragraph.text: Except as provided under paragraph (2) of this subsection, a licensee may not conduct a game on Sunday.

subparagraph.text: A licensee may operate a raffle on Sunday.
A raffle is considered to be operated on the day that the licensee selects the raffle winner.
The sheriff shall license a 50/50 game operated for a period of more than 1 day as a raffle.

paragraph.text: A licensee may not allow a child who is under the age of 16 years to:

subparagraph.text: operate a game or gaming device for which a license is issued under this subtitle;
conduct a game in which a gaming device is operated; or
play or participate in a game in which a gaming device is operated.

paragraph.text: The licensee may not pay a fee for the rental of the premises on which a game is conducted to:

subparagraph.text: itself;
a trustee of the licensee;
a committee of the licensee; or
an organization with the same members or substantially the same members as the licensee.

subsection.text: The sheriff shall charge each applicant:

paragraph.text: a license fee of $1 for each day for which a license is issued; and
the following additional amounts:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in items (ii) through (v) of this item, $1 for each gaming device to be operated each day;
$1 for each day that a pull tab or instant bingo device is to be sold;
$1 for each day that a bingo event is to be conducted;
$1 for each day that a bingo special event is to be conducted; and
$1 for each raffle to be conducted.

paragraph.text: In accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection, a principal officer of a licensee shall file a report under oath with the sheriff on the form that the sheriff provides.

subparagraph.text: A licensee that is issued a license for a period of less than 1 year shall file the report within 15 days after the date that the license expires.
A licensee that is issued a license for a period of 1 year shall file:

sub-subparagraph.text: a semiannual report on or before January 31 of the licensing year; and
an annual report within 30 days after the date that the license expires.

subparagraph.text: A licensee also shall keep a weekly report in the form that the sheriff requires.
The weekly report shall be completed under oath.
The weekly report is subject to audit at a reasonable hour by:

sub-subparagraph.text: the sheriff;
the State’s Attorney for the county; or
a representative of the sheriff or the State’s Attorney.

subsection.text: The report that a licensee submits to the sheriff shall:

paragraph.text: state whether the authorized activities were conducted:

subparagraph.text: on the dates and at the location stated in the application; and
by the regular members of the licensee without the assistance of gaming professionals;

paragraph.text: report the amount of the proceeds obtained from the licensed activities;
report the disbursements made in connection with the licensed activities; and
state that the licensee has not paid a fee for the rental of premises on which the game was conducted to:

subparagraph.text: itself;
a trustee of the licensee;
a committee of the licensee; or
any organization with the same members or substantially the same members as the licensee.

paragraph.text: There is a Gaming Advisory Committee in the county.
The members of the committee are appointed by, and serve at the pleasure of, the sheriff.
The members of the committee may not receive compensation.

subsection.text: The committee shall:

paragraph.text: recommend to the sheriff standards for reporting requirements for licensees;
examine the audits and reports required under § 13-2504 of this subtitle; and
make any other recommendations to assist the sheriff in the administration of licensing and other duties of the sheriff under this subtitle.
The sheriff shall suspend a license if the licensee fails to comply with the reporting requirements of § 13-2504 of this subtitle.
The suspension shall continue until the licensee meets the reporting requirements of § 13-2504 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section and subject to the procedures provided in subsection (c) of this section, the sheriff may not issue a new license for 1 year to a licensee that:

paragraph.text: has refused to file a report required under § 13-2504 of this subtitle; or
has failed to comply with this subtitle.
The sheriff shall notify the licensee or applicant for a license by registered mail of the sheriff’s suspension or refusal to issue a license.
The licensee or applicant may appeal the decision in writing to the sheriff within 30 days after receiving the notice from the sheriff.

section.text: A party may seek judicial review of:

paragraph.text: the sheriff’s suspension of a license under this subtitle; or
the sheriff’s refusal to issue a license under this subtitle.

section.text: This subtitle shall be enforced by:

paragraph.text: the sheriff;
any municipal police officer in the county;
any other law enforcement officer of the county; and
any prosecutor of the county.

section.text: In this subtitle, “county commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Worcester County.
This subtitle applies only in Worcester County.
In this part, “board” means the Worcester County Bingo Board.
The following organizations may conduct bingo in accordance with this part:

paragraph.text: a bona fide religious organization that has conducted religious services at a fixed location in the county for at least 6 years before applying for a license under this part;
a municipal corporation in the county;
a volunteer fire company in the county;
a local unit of a nationwide bona fide nonprofit organization or club that consists solely of members who served in the armed forces of the United States; or
a nonprofit organization that:

subparagraph.text: intends to raise money for an exclusively charitable or educational purpose that is specifically described in the license application filed with the board; and
has operated as a nonprofit organization in the county for at least 5 years before applying for a license under this part.

subsection.text: There is a Worcester County Bingo Board.
The board consists of three members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Each member of the board shall:

paragraph.text: be a registered voter of the county; and
be an owner of real property according to the assessment records of the county.
Each member of the board is entitled to:

subparagraph.text: an annual salary of at least $1,000 as determined by the county commissioners; and
a reasonable travel and expense allowance.

paragraph.text: The county commissioners shall pay the cost of the payments made under paragraph (1) of this subsection and all administrative expenses of the board from the proceeds paid to the county commissioners under this part.
The term of a member is 6 years and begins on June 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the board on October 1, 2002.
The Governor shall fill any vacancy on the board occurring during the term of an appointed member for the unexpired term with the advice and consent of the Senate.

subsection.text: The board may adopt reasonable regulations to administer and enforce this part.
A copy of the regulations adopted by the board shall be made available at a reasonable cost.

paragraph.text: The board shall exercise control and supervision over all games of bingo to ensure that the games are conducted fairly in accordance with the provisions of the licenses issued under § 13-2610 of this subtitle, the regulations adopted by the board, and this part.
The board shall prevent bingo from being conducted for a commercial purpose, for private profit, or in any manner other than as provided in this part.

subsection.text: For purposes of inspection, the board, its officers, and its agents may enter at any time any place where:

paragraph.text: bingo is being or will be conducted; or
any equipment that is being or will be used to conduct bingo is located.

subsection.text: An organization or municipal corporation described in § 13–2606 of this subtitle that intends to conduct bingo under this part must obtain:

paragraph.text: an annual license to conduct bingo for more than 15 days in a year; or
a temporary license to conduct bingo for 15 days or fewer in a year.
An applicant for a license shall submit to the board an application on the form that the board by regulation requires.
The application form shall require:

subparagraph.text: the name of the applicant;
the name of each principal officer of the applicant; and
a certification that no person will conduct bingo except a person who:

sub-subparagraph.text: is a salaried employee or bona fide member of the applicant; and
shall not receive any form of commission or bonus.

paragraph.text: An applicant shall pay to the board a license fee of:

subparagraph.text: $100 for an annual license; or
$25 in addition to $5 for each day bingo is conducted for a temporary license.

paragraph.text: The board shall pay to the county commissioners all license fees collected under this part.

subsection.text: The board shall issue a license to each applicant who meets the requirements of this part and the regulations adopted under this part.
If an applicant conducts bingo on premises that are leased by the applicant, the lease agreement must be approved by the board before a license may be issued.
The board may deny a license to an applicant or suspend or revoke a license if the applicant or licensee has violated this part or any regulation adopted under this part.
The charge for admission to a place in order to participate in bingo conducted under this part may not exceed $5.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraphs (2) and (3) of this subsection, the value of a prize in money, merchandise, or services for any one game of bingo conducted under this part may not exceed $200.
Jackpot prizes may be offered in a maximum amount of $5,000.
“Winner Take All” games may be offered without a prize limit.

subsection.text: A licensee’s employees and the terms of their employment must be approved by the board before they may conduct bingo under this part.
A minor may not be allowed to participate in bingo conducted under this part.
Bingo may not be conducted under this part in a room or area where alcoholic beverages are sold or served during the game.
A licensee under this part may not conduct bingo on more than 125 days in a year.

section.text: Unless otherwise prohibited by county or municipal law, all forms of advertising for bingo are allowed.

subsection.text: Each licensee under this part shall submit to the board, at monthly intervals or at any other interval that the board sets, a statement of its gross receipts and expenses.
For each game of bingo conducted by the licensee, the statement shall include:

paragraph.text: the amount of gross receipts derived from the game;
each item of expense incurred in the conduct of the game;
each item of expenditure made in connection with the game; and
the net profit derived from the conduct of the game.
Each licensee shall pay to the county commissioners 3% of the gross receipts derived from bingo for each day that bingo is conducted by the licensee under this part.
The licensee shall pay the money at the time the licensee submits to the board the statement required under § 13-2613 of this subtitle.
An organization described in § 13-2606(5) of this subtitle may retain up to one-half of the proceeds derived from bingo conducted under this part for the benefit of the organization.
The organization shall distribute any remaining proceeds for educational or charitable purposes.

subsection.text: If bingo is conducted in a municipal corporation in the county, the county commissioners shall pay one-third of the 3% of the gross receipts received under subsection (a) of this section to the municipal corporation, to be used for its general purposes.

paragraph.text: From the percentage of the gross receipts retained by the county commissioners, the county commissioners shall first pay the expenses necessary to administer this part.
All additional funds shall be credited by the county commissioners to the general funds of the county.

subsection.text: Each licensee under this part shall maintain the books and reports that the board requires for the purposes of this part.
The board shall submit to the county commissioners a detailed annual report of all statements submitted to the board.

paragraph.text: A licensee may not:

subparagraph.text: divert or pay out any of the proceeds of bingo conducted under this part in any manner other than as required by this part or by the regulations adopted under this part; or
violate any other provision of this part.

paragraph.text: A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to a fine not exceeding $500 for each violation.
A person may not receive any of the proceeds of bingo conducted under this part except for the purposes provided in this part.
A person who violates this subsection is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 90 days or a fine not exceeding $500 or both.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Gaming device” means a paddle wheel, wheel of fortune, chance book, raffle, or any other mechanism for playing a game of chance.
“Gaming device” does not include bingo.

subsection.text: “Multiple gaming device permit” means a permit that allows the use of two or more gaming devices.
“Raffle” means a lottery using paper chances in which prizes are won by persons who buy chances in the lottery.

section.text: This part does not authorize gambling using a slot machine or coin machine.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may issue a permit to any of the following organizations to conduct a fundraiser at which merchandise or money prizes may be awarded by gaming devices:

paragraph.text: a bona fide religious organization that has conducted religious services at the same location in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a permit;

a volunteer fire company that is supported by the county or a municipal corporation in the county or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the volunteer fire company or auxiliary unit;
a nationally chartered veterans’ organization or an auxiliary unit whose members are directly associated with the veterans’ organization;
a bona fide nonprofit fraternal, educational, civic, patriotic, or charitable organization that intends to conduct a fundraiser for the benefit of a charity located in the county; or
a bona fide nonprofit organization that:

subparagraph.text: intends to raise money for an exclusively charitable, athletic, or educational purpose that is specifically described in the permit application; and
has operated as a nonprofit organization in the county for at least 3 years before applying for a permit.

subsection.text: The county commissioners shall determine whether an organization qualifies for a permit under this section.
An organization must be organized in and serve the residents of the county to be eligible for a permit under this section.
An organization that is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code is a bona fide charity under this section.

section.text: The county commissioners may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations concerning the permit application and the issuance of permits under this part;
set a fee by resolution for each kind of permit issued under this part;
regulate the number of permits issued to organizations each year; and
deny a permit to an organization for up to 3 years if the organization violates this part or the regulations adopted under this part.

subsection.text: The county commissioners may not issue more than two multiple gaming device permits to an organization in any 1 year.
The county commissioners may not issue:

paragraph.text: more than eight multiple gaming device permits for fundraisers to be held in any one facility in any 1 year; or
more than three multiple gaming device permits for fundraisers to be held in any one facility in any 27-day period.

subsection.text: A multiple gaming device permit issued under this part is valid for only one fundraiser lasting not more than 6 hours.
The county commissioners may not issue a multiple gaming device permit for use in Ocean City or on real property that is owned by Ocean City and located in the county.
The county commissioners may not issue a multiple gaming device permit to hold a fundraiser on premises that are licensed under a Class B or Class D alcoholic beverages license.

section.text: At least one-half of the funds derived from a fundraiser for which a multiple gaming device permit has been issued under this part shall be used for a civic, charitable, or educational purpose.

subsection.text: A raffle conducted under a permit issued under this part may not last more than 1 year from the date the permit is issued to the date the last prize is awarded.
The county commissioners may regulate the number of permits to conduct a raffle that an organization may receive in a year.
A raffle is not a multiple gaming device.

subparagraph.text: A fundraiser conducted under this part shall be managed and operated only by members of the organization that receives the permit for the fundraiser.
A person may not be compensated for the management or operation of any gaming activity authorized by the permit.

paragraph.text: Each organization that receives a permit for a fundraiser under this part shall designate an individual who is responsible for complying with the terms and conditions of the permit and this part.

subsection.text: An organization that receives a permit for a fundraiser under this part shall conduct the fundraiser in:

paragraph.text: a structure that is owned, leased, or occupied by the organization;
a structure that is owned, leased, or occupied by an organization that would qualify for a permit under § 13-2621 of this subtitle; or
a public location that is described in the permit application and approved by the State’s Attorney for the county.

section.text: Within 30 days after a fundraiser conducted under this part, the organization that received the permit for the fundraiser shall submit to the county commissioners:

paragraph.text: an accounting of all funds received or pledged;
an accounting of all expenses paid or incurred; and
a statement under oath of the application of the net profits.

subsection.text: A person who violates this part is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 1 year or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.
Each day on which a violation of this part occurs is a separate violation.
In this section, “crime of violence” means:

paragraph.text: abduction;
arson in the first degree;
kidnapping;
manslaughter, except involuntary manslaughter;
mayhem;
maiming, as previously proscribed under former Article 27, §§ 385 and 386 of the Code;
murder;
rape;
robbery under § 3–402 or § 3–403 of this article;
carjacking;
armed carjacking;
sexual offense in the first degree;
sexual offense in the second degree;
use of a handgun in the commission of a felony or other crime of violence;
child abuse in the first degree under § 3–601 of this article;
sexual abuse of a minor under § 3–602 of this article if:

subparagraph.text: the victim is under the age of 13 years and the offender is an adult at the time of the offense; and
the offense involved:

sub-subparagraph.text: vaginal intercourse, as defined in § 3–301 of this article;
a sexual act, as defined in § 3–301 of this article;
an act in which a part of the offender’s body penetrates, however slightly, into the victim’s genital opening or anus; or
the intentional touching, not through the clothing, of the victim’s or the offender’s genital, anal, or other intimate area for sexual arousal, gratification, or abuse;

paragraph.text: an attempt to commit any of the crimes described in items (1) through (16) of this subsection;
continuing course of conduct with a child under § 3–315 of this article;
assault in the first degree;
assault with intent to murder;
assault with intent to rape;
assault with intent to rob;
assault with intent to commit a sexual offense in the first degree; and
assault with intent to commit a sexual offense in the second degree.

subsection.text: This section does not apply if a person is sentenced to death.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in subsection (g) of this section, on conviction for a fourth time of a crime of violence, a person who has served three separate terms of confinement in a correctional facility as a result of three separate convictions of any crime of violence shall be sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.
Notwithstanding any other law, the provisions of this subsection are mandatory.

Except as provided in subsection (g) of this section, on conviction for a third time of a crime of violence, a person shall be sentenced to imprisonment for the term allowed by law but not less than 25 years, if the person:

subparagraph.text: has been convicted of a crime of violence on two prior separate occasions:

sub-subparagraph.text: in which the second or succeeding crime is committed after there has been a charging document filed for the preceding occasion; and
for which the convictions do not arise from a single incident; and

subparagraph.text: has served at least one term of confinement in a correctional facility as a result of a conviction of a crime of violence.

paragraph.text: The court may not suspend all or part of the mandatory 25–year sentence required under this subsection.
A person sentenced under this subsection is not eligible for parole except in accordance with the provisions of § 4–305 of the Correctional Services Article.

On conviction for a second time of a crime of violence committed on or after October 1, 1994, a person shall be sentenced to imprisonment for the term allowed by law, but not less than 10 years, if the person:

subparagraph.text: has been convicted on a prior occasion of a crime of violence, including a conviction for a crime committed before October 1, 1994; and
served a term of confinement in a correctional facility for that conviction.

paragraph.text: The court may not suspend all or part of the mandatory 10–year sentence required under this subsection.

subsection.text: If the State intends to proceed against a person as a subsequent offender under this section, it shall comply with the procedures set forth in the Maryland Rules for the indictment and trial of a subsequent offender.

paragraph.text: A person sentenced under this section may petition for and be granted parole if the person:

subparagraph.text: is at least 65 years old; and
has served at least 15 years of the sentence imposed under this section.

paragraph.text: The Maryland Parole Commission shall adopt regulations to implement this subsection.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, if a law sets a maximum and a minimum penalty for a crime, the court may impose instead of the minimum penalty a lesser penalty of the same character.
This section does not affect:

paragraph.text: a maximum penalty fixed by law; or
the punishment for any crime for which the statute provides one and only one penalty.

section.text: Any claim to dispensation from punishment by benefit of clergy is abolished.
